The First Volume of the Book of The Meccan Revelations (الفتوحات المكية), which Allah disclosed to the Shaykh, the Imam, the Active, the Firmly Rooted, the Perfect, the Seal of the Inheriting Saints (خاتم الأولياء الوارثين), the Isthmus of Isthmuses (برزخ البرازخ), the Reviver of the Truth and the Religion (محيي الحق و الدين), Abu Abdullah Muhammad ibn Ali, known as Ibn Arabi al-Hatimi al-Ta'i. May Allah sanctify his soul and illuminate his tomb. Amen. Printed based on the copy collated against the author's manuscript found in the city of Konya. This task was undertaken by a group of scholars by order of the late Amir Abd al-Qadir al-Jaza'irli (May Allah have mercy on them all and grant them a high station). Printed at the Great Arabic Book Press in Egypt at the expense of Al-Hajj Fida Muhammad al-Kashmiri and his partners.

In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful. (May Allah bless our Master Muhammad.)

### The Sermon of the Book

### Reflections on the Reality of Existence

Praise be to Allah, Who brought things into existence (أوجد الأشياء) from non-existence (عدم) and its non-being, and conditioned their existence upon the direction of a Word (كلمة), so that we may thereby realize the secret of their contingency (حدوثها) and their pre-eternity (قدمها) from His Pre-eternity. And by this realization, we stand upon what He has informed us concerning the truth of His Pre-eternity. Thus, He—Glory be to Him—manifested (ظهر), and He was manifested, and He caused to manifest (أظهر); and He was hidden (بطن), but He was hidden, and He caused to be hidden (أبطن). The Name 'The First' (الاسم الأول) was established for Him by the existence of the essence of the servant, which was already established. And the Name 'The Last' (الاسم الآخر) was established for Him by the decree of annihilation (الفناء) and loss, which was already established before that.

Were it not for the age and the contemporary, the ignorant and the knowledgeable, no one would have known the meaning of His Name 'The First' and 'The Last,' nor 'The Hidden' (الباطن) and 'The Manifest' (الظاهر). Although His Beautiful Names (أسماؤه الحسنى) follow this most sublime path, there is a distinction between them in their stations (المنازل), which becomes clear when means are adopted for the descent of calamities. Thus, the servant of the Forbearing (عبد الحليم) is not the servant of the Generous (عبد الكريم), and the servant of the Forgiving (عبد الغفور) is not the servant of the Thankful (عبد الشكور). Every servant has a Name that is his Lord, and the body of that Name is his heart. He is the All-Knowing (العليم)—Glory be to Him—Who knew and taught; the Judge (الحاكم) Who judged and decreed; the Subduer (القاهر) Who subdued and compelled; and the Powerful (القادر) Who decreed and acquired, yet did not decree the Everlasting (الباقي) in Whom the attribute of Subsistence (البقاء) does not reside. He is the Holy One (المقدس), exalted during the witnessing (المشاهدة) from direct confrontation and encounter. Rather, it is the servant in that most pure station (الموطن الأنزه) who is entitled to transcendence (التنزيه), not that He—Glory and Exaltation be to Him—in that most pure station is subject to similitude (التشبيه). Thus, directions vanish from the servant in that Presence (الحضرة), and when the gaze rises through Him, distraction ceases from the servant. I praise Him with the praise of one who knows that He—Glory be to Him—is exalted in His Attributes (صفاته) and High, and Majestic in His Essence (ذاته) and Manifest; and that the veil of Might (حجاب العزة) is drawn before Him—Glory be to Him—and the door to attaining the Gnosis of His Essence (معرفة ذاته) is locked. If He addresses His servant, He is the Hearer, the All-Hearing (السميع); and if the servant performs what he was commanded to perform, He is the Obeyed, the Obedient (المطيع). When this Reality (الحقيقة) perplexed me, I recited, according to the rule of the Path (الطريقة), for the Caliph:

> The Lord is the Real (الحق) and the servant is the real.
> O, would that I knew who is charged with the duty (المكلف)?
> If I say 'servant,' that one is dead.
> Or if I say 'Lord,' how can He be charged with duty?

Thus, He—Glory be to Him—obeys Himself when He wills to create him, and He does justice to Himself concerning what was incumbent upon Him from His necessary right. There are only empty specters (أشباح خالية) upon their desolate thrones. In the echoing of the sound (ترجيع الصدى) lies the secret we alluded to for whoever is guided. And I thank Him with the gratitude of one who realized that through the charging with duty (التكليف), the Worshipped Name (الاسم المعبود) became manifest, and through the existence of the reality of "There is no power and no strength save in Allah," the reality of Generosity (الجود) became manifest. Otherwise, if Paradise is made a reward for what you have done, where is the Divine Generosity (الجود الإلهي) that you comprehended? For you are veiled (محجوب) from the knowledge that you are gifted for your own Essence (ذاتك), and from the knowledge of the origin of your soul. If that by which you seek reward is not yours, how do you regard your action? So, leave things to their Creator, and provisions to their Provider. He—Glory be to Him—is the Giver (الواهب) Who never tires, and the King (الملك) Whose sovereignty is mighty and majestic, the Subtle (اللطيف) with His servants, the All-Aware (الخبير), <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ وهُوَ السَّمِيعُ الْبَصِيرُ>> (There is nothing like unto Him, and He is the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing).

### Reflections on the Muhammadan Reality

And blessings be upon the Secret and Quintessence of the World (سر العالم ونكتته), the World's Goal and Desire, the truthful Master who journeyed by night (المدلج) to his Lord, the Knocker, penetrating through the Seven Paths (السبع الطرائق), so that the One Who carried him by night might show him the signs (الآيات) and realities (الحقائق) He deposited within the creation (الخلائق) He originated. Him whom I witnessed while composing this sermon, in the world of the realities of similitude (عالم حقائق المثال), in the Presence of Majesty (حضرة الجلال), a cardiac unveiling (مكاشفة قلبيه) in a Presence of the Unseen (حضرة غيبية). When I witnessed him (peace and blessings be upon him) in that world, he was a Master, infallible in his intentions, preserved in his witnessing, victorious, and supported. All the Messengers were arrayed before him, and his community, which is the best community, was gathered around him. The angels of subjugation (ملائكة التسخير) were surrounding the throne of his station, and the angels generated from deeds were lined up before him. Al-Siddiq (Abu Bakr) was on his most precious right, and Al-Faruq (Umar) was on his most holy left. The Seal (الختم) was before him, kneeling, informing him of the discourse of the female (حديث الأنثى). Ali (peace and blessings be upon him) was translating for the Seal with his tongue, and Dhun-Nurayn (Uthman) was wrapped in the cloak of his modesty, attending to his own affair.

Then the Most High Master, the Sweetest and Purest Source, and the Most Manifest and Clear Light turned, and saw me behind the Seal (الختم) due to a shared ruling between us. The Master said to him: "This is your counterpart, your son, and your intimate friend. Erect for him the pulpit of tamarisk (منبر الطرفاء) before me." Then he signaled to me: "Arise, O Muhammad, ascend it and praise the One Who sent me, and praise me. For in you is a hair from me that has no patience for separation from me. It is the sovereign (السلطانة) in your essentiality (ذاتيتك). So, do not return to me except with your totality. And it must return to the Encounter (اللقاء), for it is not from the world of misery (الشقاء)." Nothing that came from me after my sending, in anything, was anything but blessed, and I was among those who gave thanks and were praised in the Highest Assembly (الملإ الأعلى). So the Seal erected the pulpit in that most momentous scene, and upon the forehead of the pulpit was written in the most radiant light: "This is the Purest Muhammadan Station (المقام المحمدي الأطهر). Whoever ascends it has inherited it, and the Real (الحق) has sent him forth, preserving the sanctity of the Law (الشريعة), and resurrected him."

At that moment, I was granted the gifts of wisdom (الحكم) until it was as if I had been given the comprehensive words (جوامع الكلم). I thanked Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, and ascended to its highest point, reaching the place where he (peace and blessings be upon him) stood and his level. A sleeve of a white shirt was spread out for me on the step where I stood, so that I would not directly touch the place he (peace and blessings be upon him) had touched with his feet, out of reverence and honor for him, and as an indication and instruction for us that the station he witnessed from his Lord is not witnessed by the inheritors except from behind his garment. Were it not for that, we would have unveiled what he unveiled and known what he knew. Do you not see that the one who follows his trace to learn his news does not witness, through the path of his spiritual journey (سلوكه), what he witnessed, nor does he know how to report the removal of attributes from him? For instance, he witnessed level dust with no attribute, and he walked upon it. You, following his trace, see nothing but the imprint of his feet. Herein lies a hidden secret (سر خفي): if you search for it, you will reach it. It is because he is an Imam (leader) and has attained the Imām (the one who leads); he neither witnesses a trace nor knows it, for he has unveiled what is not unveiled. This station appeared in the denial of Moses (peace and blessings be upon our Master and upon him) concerning Al-Khidr. When I stood in that most sublime position before the one who was, on the night of his Ascension (إسرائه), <<قابَ قَوْسَيْنِ أَوْ أَدْنى‏>> (two bow-lengths or nearer), I stood veiled and ashamed. Then I was supported by the Holy Spirit (روح القدس) and began extemporaneously:

> O Revealer of Signs (الآيات) and Tidings,
> Reveal to me the landmarks of the Names (الأسماء).
> So that I may be a collector of the praise of Your Essence (ذاتك),
> Through the praises of ease and hardship.

Then I pointed to him (peace and blessings be upon him):

> And this Master, the banner, whom
> You stripped of the cycle of Caliphs,
> And made him the Noble Origin, while Adam
> Was between the clay of his creation and the water.
> And You transferred him until his time revolved,
> And You bent his end back upon the beginning.
> And You established him as a humble, submissive servant,
> For an age, communing with You in the Cave of Hira.
> Until Gabriel, specialized in tidings,
> Came to him as a bearer of good news from You.
> He said: "Peace be upon you, you are Muhammad,
> The Secret of the servants and the Seal of the Prophets."
> "O my Master, I speak truly," and he said to me:
> "You have spoken truthfully, for you are the shadow of my cloak."
> "So praise and increase the praise of your Lord diligently,
> For the realities of things (حقائق الأشياء) have been gifted to you."
> "And scatter for us from the affair of your Lord what was unveiled,
> To your heart, preserved in the darkness,
> Of every Reality (حق) established by an essence (حقيقة),
> That comes to you enslaved without purchase."

### The Origin of the Cosmos and the Manifestation of Beings

Then I began to speak with the tongue of the All-Knower (العلام). I said, pointing to him (peace and blessings be upon him): I praised the One Who revealed to you the Hidden Book (الكتاب المكنون), <<الَّذِي لَا يَمَسُّهُ إِلَّا الْمُطَهَّرُونَ>> (which none shall touch save the purified), revealed through your excellent character, your transcendence (تنزيهك) from defects, and your sanctification. So He said in Surah Nun: <<بِسْمِ الله الرَّحْمنِ الرَّحِيمِ ن والْقَلَمِ وما يَسْطُرُونَ ما أَنْتَ بِنِعْمَةِ رَبِّكَ بِمَجْنُونٍ وإِنَّ لَكَ لَأَجْراً غَيْرَ مَمْنُونٍ وإِنَّكَ لَعَلى‏ خُلُقٍ عَظِيمٍ فَسَتُبْصِرُ ويُبْصِرُونَ>> (In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful. Nun. By the pen and what they inscribe, you are not, by the favor of your Lord, mad. And indeed, for you is a reward uninterrupted. And indeed, you are upon a tremendous character. Soon you will see, and they will see). Then He dipped the Pen of Will (قلم الإرادة) into the Ink of Knowledge (مداد العلم) and inscribed with the Right Hand of Power (يمين القدرة) upon the guarded Preserved Tablet (اللوح المحفوظ) everything that was, everything that is, and everything that will be, and what will not be—which, had He willed it to be (though He does not will it), would have been—how it would be, according to His known, measured decree and His noble, hidden knowledge. <<سُبْحانَ رَبِّكَ رَبِّ الْعِزَّةِ عَمَّا يَصِفُونَ>> (Exalted is your Lord, the Lord of Might, above what they describe). That is Allah, the One, the Unique. Exalted is He above what the polytheists associate with Him.

The first Name that sublime Pen wrote, before any other Name, was: "I desire to create, for your sake, O Muhammad, the World (العالم) which is your dominion. So I create the Jewel of Water (جوهرة الماء)." So I created it without the most protected Veil of Might (حجاب العزة الأحمى), and I was upon what I was, with nothing alongside Me, in the Cloud (عما). So He—Glory be to Him—created the water as a solid, cold mass, like a jewel in its roundness and whiteness, and deposited within it, potentially, the essences of bodies and the essences of accidents. Then He created the Throne (العرش), and His Name, the Most Compassionate (الرحمن), settled upon it. He erected the Footstool (الكرسي), and the two Feet hung down toward it. He looked with the Eye of Majesty (عين الجلال) upon that Jewel, and it melted out of modesty, and its parts dissolved, becoming water. <<وَكَانَ عَرْشُهُ عَلَى ذَلِكَ الْمَاءِ>> (And His Throne was upon that water) before the existence of the earth and the sky. At that time, there existed nothing but the realities (حقائق) of the One Who settled upon it, the one who settled, and the settling itself.

Then He sent forth the Breath (النفس), and the water surged from its agitation, foamed, and sounded the praise of the Praised, the Real (الحق), when it struck the shore of the Throne. The Leg (الساق) shook and said to it, "I am Ahmad." The water was ashamed and retreated backward, seeking its depth, leaving its foam on the shore it had produced. That foam is the churning of that water, which contains most things. From that foam, He—Glory be to Him—originated the Earth, round in its formation, praised in its length and breadth. Then He originated the smoke from the fire generated by the friction of the Earth when it was split open. In that smoke, He split open the high heavens (السموات العلي) and made it the place of lights (الأنوار) and the stations of the Highest Assembly (الملإ الأعلى). He matched the luminous stars adorning the heavens with the flowering plants adorning the Earth. He—Exalted is He—singled out Adam and his two sons with His Essence (ذاته), which is exalted above similitude (التشبيه), and His two Hands.

So He established a corporeal formation (نشأة جسدية) and perfected it with two perfections: the perfection of the expiration of its term and the acceptance of its eternity. He made the dwelling of this formation the point of the sphere of Existence (كرة الوجود) and concealed its essence. Then He alerted His servants to it by His saying: <<بِغَيْرِ عَمَدٍ تَرَوْنَها>> (without pillars that you see). When man transitions to the Isthmus (برزخ) of the animal abode, the dome of the sky will surge and split, becoming a flowing flame of fire like molten oil. Whoever understands the realities of the relations (حقائق الإضافات) will know the allusions we mentioned to him. He will know with certainty that a dome does not stand without pillars, just as a father cannot exist without having a child. The pillar (العمد) is the holding meaning. If you do not wish it to be man, then make it the Power of the Sovereign (قدرة المالك). Thus, it becomes clear that there must be a holder that holds it, and since it is a dominion, it must have a sovereign who owns it. The one for whose sake it is held is its holder, and the one for whose cause it exists is its sovereign.

When the realities (حقائق) of the blessed (السعداء) and the wretched (الأشقياء) perceived, at the grasp of Power upon them between non-existence (العدم) and existence (الوجود)—which is the state of origination—the beauty of the end through the eye of conformity and guidance, and the evil of the outcome through the eye of opposition and misguidance, the blessed hastened toward existence, while hesitation and refusal appeared from the wretched. For this reason, the Real (الحق) informed us about the state of the blessed, saying: <<أُولئِكَ يُسارِعُونَ في الْخَيْراتِ وهُمْ لَها سابِقُونَ>> (Those hasten to good deeds, and they are foremost in them), referring to that speed. And He said concerning the wretched: <<فَثَبَّطَهُمْ وقِيلَ اقْعُدُوا مَعَ الْقاعِدِينَ>> (So He held them back, and it was said, 'Remain with those who remain'), referring to that retreat. Were it not for the blowing of those breaths (النفحات) upon the bodies, no traveler (سالك) of error or guidance would have appeared in this world. Because of that speed and hesitation, you informed us (peace and blessings be upon you) that Allah's Mercy preceded His Wrath—thus the narrator attributed it to you.

Then He—Glory be to Him—originated the Realities (الحقائق) according to the number of His Names (أسماء حقه), and manifested the angels of subjugation (ملائكة التسخير) according to the number of His creation (خلقه). He assigned to every reality a Name from His Names, which it worships and knows, and He assigned to every secret reality an angel that serves and adheres to it. Among the realities, there are those whose vision of themselves veiled them from their Name, so they departed from their duty (تكليفه) and its ruling, and they were among the deniers. And among them are those whose feet Allah made firm, who took their Name as their Imam (leader), established the sign between themselves and it, and made it their leader, so they were among the prostrating ones.

Then He extracted from the First Father the lights of the Poles (أنوار الأقطاب) as suns swimming in the orbits of the Stations (المقامات), and He extracted the lights of the Nobles (أنوار النجباء) as stars swimming in the orbits of the Miracles (الكرامات). He established the Four Pegs (الأوتاد الأربعة) for the four corners, and by them, the two weighty ones (mankind and jinn) were preserved. They removed the shaking and movement of the Earth, so it became still. It was adorned with the jewelry of its flowers and the robes of its plants, and it brought forth its blessing. Thus, the sight of creation was delighted by its splendid view, their sense of smell by its fragrant scent, and their palates by its delicious taste. Then He sent the Seven Substitutes (الأبدال السبعة), the sending of a Wise, All-Knowing One, as kings over the Seven Climes (الأقاليم). Each Substitute has a clime, and He made the two Imams (الإمامين) ministers to the Pole (القطب), establishing them as leaders over the two reins.

When He originated the World (العالم) with the utmost perfection, and nothing more wondrous remained possible, as Imam Abu Hamid said concerning possibility, and He manifested your body (peace and blessings be upon you) to sight, the narrator reported that you said one day in your assembly: "Indeed, Allah was, and there was nothing with Him, but He is upon what He was." Thus are the realities of the universes (حقائق الأكوان), peace and blessings be upon you. This Reality (الحقيقة) did not surpass all other realities except by being prior while they are subsequent. For whoever is not with anything, nothing is with him. If the realities had emerged differently from how they were in Knowledge (العلم), they would have been distinct from the Transcendent Reality (الحقيقة المنزهة) by this ruling. Thus, the realities are now, in the ruling, as they were in Knowledge. Let us say: they were, and nothing was with them in their existence, and they are now as they were in the knowledge of their Worshipped One.

This report, which was applied to the Real (الحق), has encompassed all creation (الخلق). Do not object to the multiplicity of causes and effects, for they will counter you with the existence of the Names (الأسماء) and Attributes (الصفات), even though the meanings they indicate are diverse. Were it not for a connecting cause and a correct, regulating acquisition (كسب صحيح ضابط) between the beginning and the end, neither would be known by the other, nor would it be said that the Last is established by the ruling of the First. There is nothing but the Lord and the servant, and that is sufficient. In this is richness and healing for whoever desires the gnosis of his soul in Existence (الوجود). Do you not see that the conclusion is the very essence of the preceding, and it is a necessary, truthful Word? Why does man feign ignorance, become blind, and walk in dark gloom where there is neither shade nor water? The truest news heard, brought by the hoopoe of understanding from Sheba, is the existence of the encompassing Sphere (الفلك المحيط) found in the composite and simple World (العالم), named the Primordial Dust (الهباء), and the closest things to it are water and air, even though they are among the forms opened within it.

Since this Sphere is the origin of Existence (أصل الوجود), and His Name, the Light (النور), disclosed itself (تجلى) to it from the Presence of Generosity (حضرة الجود), manifestation occurred. Your form (peace and blessings be upon you) received the first effusion (فيض) of that Light from that Sphere, and a similitudinal form (صورة مثلية) appeared: its witnessings (مشاهدها) are essential, its sources (مشاربها) are unseen, its Paradise is Edenic, its gnoses (معارفها) are of the Pen, its sciences are of the Right Hand, its secrets (أسرارها) are of the ink, its spirits (أرواحها) are of the Tablet, and its clay is Adamite. Thus, you are a father to us in spirituality (الروحانية), just as Adam (peace and blessings be upon him)—and I pointed to him in that gathering—was a father to us in corporeality. The elements are a mother and father to him, just as the reality of the Primordial Dust (الهباء) was originally with the One. No matter comes about except from two matters, and no result except from two premises. Is not your existence dependent upon the Real (الحق)—Glory be to Him—and His being Powerful? And are not your rulings upon Him derived from His being described as All-Knowing? And is not your specialization in one matter over another, despite its permissibility for you, derived from His being known as Willing? The existence of the non-existent (المعدوم) cannot be soundly derived from the Unique Essence, for how can the 'where' (الأين) be conceived from the 'where'? The essence of the thing must necessarily be a 'where' for some matter, which is unknown to him who has become blind to the unveiling (الكشف) of the realities (الحقائق). In the gnosis of the Attribute (الصفة) and the Described (الموصوف), the reality of the known 'where' becomes clear. Otherwise, how could you (peace and blessings be upon you) be asked with 'where' (أين) and accept the preposition of location (فاء الظرف) from the one questioned, and then bear witness to her pure faith? Your testimony is a reality, not a metaphor, a necessity, not a possibility. Were it not for your gnosis (معرفتك), peace and blessings be upon you, of the reality of what she said, you would not have accepted her statement, despite her being mute in the sky.

Then, after He brought into existence the subtle and dense worlds (العوالم اللطيفة والكثيفة), prepared the dominion, and arranged the noble station, He sent down the Caliph (الخليفة) in the first cycle of Virgo. For this reason, He—Glory be to Him—made our duration in this world seven thousand years. At its end, a state of annihilation (فناء) between sleep and slumber will befall us. We will then transition to the Isthmus (البرزخ) that gathers the paths, where the flying realities (الحقائق الطيارة) will overcome all other realities. The dominion will return to the spirits (الأرواح), and their Caliph at that time will be a bird with six hundred wings. The specters (الأشباح) will be seen as subordinate to the spirits, and man will transform into any form he wishes, corresponding to a reality established for him at the Resurrection (البعث) from the graves during the origination. This depends on the market of Paradise, the market of subtleties and grace.

Look, may Allah have mercy on you—and I pointed to Adam—at the white emerald (الزمردة البيضاء) that the Most Compassionate deposited in the first of the fathers. Look at the Manifest Light (النور المبين)—and I pointed to the Second Father who named us Muslims. Look at the purest silver (اللجين الأخلص)—and I pointed to the one who healed the blind and the leper by Allah's permission, as the text states. Look at the beauty of the redness of the ruby of the soul (ياقوتة النفس)—and I pointed to the one who was sold <<بِثَمَنٍ بَخْسٍ>> (for a meager price). Look at the redness of the refined gold (حمرة الإبريز)—and I pointed to the Mighty Caliph (الخليفة العزيز). Look at the light of the yellow ruby in the darkness—and I pointed to the one favored with speech. Whoever strives toward these Lights until he reaches the secrets (الأسرار) that their path unveils for him, has known the station (المرتبة) for which he was found, and the Divine Station (المقام الآلي) was confirmed for him, and to him He prostrated. Thus, he is the Lord and the Lorded, the Lover and the Beloved.

> Look at the beginning of Existence (الوجود) and be
> Discerning in it, you will see the ancient, contingent Generosity.
> And the thing is like the thing, except that He
> Manifested it contingently in the essence of the worlds.
> If the seer swears that his existence
> Is eternal (أزلا), he is a truthful righteous one who will not break his oath.
> Or if the seer swears that his existence
> Is more fittingly from his loss, and it was threefold.

Then I revealed secrets (أسرارا) and recounted tidings that time does not permit to mention, and whose origination most of creation does not know. So I left them suspended at the head of their path, fearing to place wisdom in an improper place. Then I was returned from that sublime dream-vision (المشهد النومي العلي) to the lower world (العالم السفلي). I made that sacred praise the sermon (خطبة) of the book and proceeded to complete its introduction. After that, I shall begin the discourse on the arrangement of the chapters (الأبواب). Praise be to Allah, the Rich, the Bestower.

### Letter to Shaykh Abd al-Aziz al-Mahdawi

This is a letter I wrote, saying: To proceed:

> When my body reached the beautiful Kaaba,
> And attained the rank of the trustworthy ones,
> And strove and circumambulated, and then prayed
> At its station, and established him among the freed ones—
> The one who said this act is a necessary duty,
> That hoped-for Seal of the Prophets (خاتم النباء).
> And my heart saw the Noble Assembly (الملأ الكريم) and Adam there,
> So it was among their peers.
> And Adam had a pious, obedient son,
> Great in generosity, the noblest of the noble.
> And all were circumambulating the honored House,
> While He was hidden in the black garment.
> He lets down the fringes of His cloak to show you
> In that strutting the pride of arrogance.
> And my father was placed before the Noble Assembly,
> Walking with the weakest gait of the chronically ill.
> And the servant, before his father, was bowed down,
> The action of the polite one, and Gabriel was beside me,
> Revealing the landmarks and rites of service
> To my father, so that he might bequeath them to his sons.
> I wondered at them, how they all spoke
> Of the corruption of our father and the shedding of blood,
> Since he veiled them with the darkness of clay
> From the radiance of the Names (الأسماء) that it contained.
> And He appeared with a Light in which there was none other than Him,
> But they were witnesses to Him therein.
> If our father was a comprehensive locus
> For the saints (الأولياء) together with the enemies,
> And he saw the little water and the little light come
> Reluctantly, without desire or purity.
> Then by the very thing by which his opposites arose,
> They judged him with harshness and vulgarity.
> And he came saying, "I am the Glorifier, and the one who
> Has never ceased praising You morning and evening."
> "And I am the Sanctifier of the Essence of Your Majesty,"
> Yet they came with every harshness against my father.
> When they saw the direction of the North, and did not see
> From him the right of the White Hand.
> And they saw their souls and humble servants,
> And they saw Him as a Lord seeking dominion,
> For a reality that gathered for him the Names of the One
> Who singled out the Beloved on the Night of the Ascension (الإسراء).
> And they saw the contention of the accursed one with his soldiers,
> Gazing at him with the eye of hatred.
> And in the essence of our father, his own hypocrite essence,
> The portion of the disobedient and the two desires of Eve.
> They knew that war was certainly coming
> From him, without hesitation or refusal.
> That is why they did not speak what they spoke,
> So excuse them, for they are among the righteous.
> They were created upon universal goodness by nature,
> They do not know the places of enmity.
> And whenever you saw my father and them in an assembly,
> He was the Imam, and they were the servants.
> And our Lord returned their saying against them
> In justice, so He lowered them to the enemies.
> For the warfare of the Noble Assembly (الملأ الكريم) is a punishment
> For their saying concerning the first of the fathers.
> Do you not see their war on the Day of Badr,
> While our Prophet was in grace and ease,
> On his canopy, supplicating and humbling himself
> To his God for the victory of the weak?
> When my heart, preserved from desires, saw all these realities,
> It called out, so let every seeker of wisdom hear,
> Who folds his cloak for it upon a swift she-camel,
> Folding like one who hopes for the encounter with his desire,
> Traversing every desolate wilderness.
> O traveler who crosses the deserts, heading
> Toward me, to attain the rank of the dark-skinned one,
> Say to the one you meet from my trees
> A word from me, the most sincere of advice-givers:
> "Know that you are lost in confusion,
> Because you were ignorant of my message and my call."
> "Indeed, the person I have always sought
> I found in the green hill (الربوة الخضراء)."
> The radiant city, the city of Tunis,
> The green, adorned, and glorious one,
> In his most sublime station, whose soil is sanctified
> By his dwelling, the one with the crooked Qibla.
> In a select, chosen group,
> From the description of the Nobles (النجباء) and the Chiefs (النقباء).
> He walks with them in the light of guiding knowledge,
> From his guidance, by the clear Sunnah.
> And the remembrance is recited, and gnoses (المعارف) are unveiled
> There, from evening to evening.
> A full moon for fourteen nights, never seen
> Illuminating a moonlit night.
> And Ibn al-Murabit is one of his affair therein,
> His realities are too majestic to be disclosed.
> And his sons surround the throne of his station,
> So he is the Imam, and they are the Substitutes (البدلاء).
> It is as if he and they, in an assembly,
> Are a full moon surrounded by the stars of the sky.
> And if he comes to you with celestial wisdom,
> It is as if he is reporting about the Phoenix (العنقاء).
> I adhered to him until a female settled with him,
> Who had a son from the strangers:
> A scholar of scholars, enamored of his soul,
> The secret of jesting, the master of elegance,
> From the group of observers and jurists,
> But he is among the virtuous among them.
> He arrived while I had the intention of supererogatory prayer
> At all times, in darkness and light.
> So I left him and traveled away from him, and with him
> Was a change from me, the jealousy of the literati.
> And he began to address me, saying, "You betrayed me
> Concerning my progeny and my ancient companions.
> And you took our penitent, by whom my house was established,
> And you did not inform my trees about him."
> But Allah knows my intention and my inner thought
> Regarding his penitent and the truth of my loyalty.
> For we adhere to the ancient covenant,
> And his affection is pure from impurities.
> And whenever you encounter a seeker of wisdom,
> Hidden in the fresh, fair-skinned one,
> Perplexed, yearning, we say to him:
> "O seeker of secrets (الأسرار) in the Night Journey (الإسراء),
> Hasten, for your hands have seized a collector
> Of the realities of the dead and the living."
> He looked at Existence (الوجود), and it was beneath his sandals,
> From his station to the bottom of the water.
> There is no ultimate goal above him to which one bows,
> Except Him, for He is the Disposer of things.
> He wore the cloak (الرداء) in transcendence (تنزها) and His wrapper (إزاره)
> When He desired the formation of origination (الإنشاء).
> But if He desires enjoyment in His Existence,
> Without looking at the observers,
> He lifts the cloak, not being arrogant,
> And the wrapper of veneration over His peers.
> Thus, an Existence (وجود) appeared that is not restricted for us
> By an attribute (صفة) or a Name (اسم) from the Names.
> If it is asked, "Who is this, and whom do you mean?"
> We say, "The Realizer, the Commander of Commanders,
> The Sun of Reality, its Pole (قطبها), and its Imam,
> The Secret of the servants and the Scholar of scholars,
> A servant whose face is darkened by his concern,
> The Light of insights, the Seal of the Caliphs (خاتم الخلفاء),
> Easy in character, good, sweet in fruit,
> The Succor of creation, the Most Merciful of the merciful.
> The attributes of His Majesty and His Beauty
> And the splendor of His Might are too majestic for peers.
> He executes the Will among the sons, dividing
> Between the deaf servants and the hired laborers.
> He is sharp if you contend with him in his dominion,
> He is soft if you come to him seeking a gift.
> Firm, yet gentle to those who seek his pardon,
> Like water flowing from a solid rock.
> He enriches and impoverishes whom He wills, for His command
> Is the reviver of the governors and the destroyer of the enemies.
> I do not forget when the Imam spoke a word
> That the most eloquent orator falls short of:
> 'We were by us, and the cloak and the prayer were a collector
> Of our essences, for we are where my cloak is.'
> Look at the hidden secret (السر المكتم), a polished pearl
> In the blind abyss.
> Until creation is perplexed in defining it,
> An essence like the ink of the return to the beginning.
> How wondrous it is that its shells did not conceal it!
> The sun dispels the darkness of the gloom.
> If a servant comes with the secret thus,
> It is said: 'Write down my servant among the trustworthy ones.'
> If he reveals the secret while it is veiled,
> My earth does not know it, so how can my sky?
> When I brought forth some description of His Majesty,
> Since the inarticulate one was standing beside me,
> They said: 'You have attached him to our God
> In Essence (الذات), Attributes (الأوصاف), and Names (الأسماء).'
> 'By what meaning do you know the Real (الحق) Who
> Created you as a creation in the darkness of the wombs?'
> We said: 'You spoke truly. But did anyone truly know
> The Originator of the universal cosmos besides me?'
> So if I praise, I only praise
> Myself, for my soul is the very essence of my praise.
> And if I desire to know His Existence (وجوده),
> I divide what I have among the creditors.
> And I became non-existent from my eye, so His Existence was.
> Thus, His manifestation is dependent upon my concealment.
> Exalted is the True God (الإله الحق) that He should appear to us
> Singularly, while my eye is manifest and my subsistence (بقائي) remains.
> If that were the case, He would be a singular one, seeking,
> Spying, spying for my praise.
> This is impossible. So let His Existence be sound
> In my absence from His eye and my annihilation (فنائي).
> So when I appear to you, I conceal Him,
> Concealing the essence of the sun in the clouds.
> The observers see before their eyes
> Clouds driven by the hand of desires.
> And the sun behind the cloud reveals its light
> To the clouds and the eyes in the darkness.
> He says: 'It has been stingy with me,' yet it is
> Busy dissolving its parts,
> To bestow abundant rain upon the earth,
> Without effort or fatigue.
> Likewise, when it rises in its light,
> It erases the rising of every star of the sky.
> But when it passes an hour after sunset,
> The stars of Orion appear to your eye.
> This is for its dead, and that is for its living,
> In its Essence, and it says, 'A beautiful vision.'
> So His concealment is for our sake, and His manifestation
> Is for His sake, and the symbol is in the shadows.
> Like our concealment is for His sake, and our manifestation
> Is for our sake, so His radiance is the very essence of my light.
> Then I turned in reverse, a second symbol,
> Whose benefits are too majestic to be counted.
> It is as if we are equal in our essences (أعياننا),
> Like the purity of the glass in the purity of the wine.
> Knowledge (العلم) witnesses sincere harmony,
> And the eye gives one thing to the viewer.
> The spirit (الروح) is delighted by the Originator of its Essence,
> And by its Essence, from the side of the peers.
> And the sense is delighted by the vision of its Lord,
> If it is absent from the sensation of blessings.
> Allah is the Greatest, and Greatness is my cloak,
> And Light is my full moon, and Radiance is my intelligence.
> The East is my West, and the Wests are my East,
> And distance is my nearness, and proximity is my remoteness.
> Fire is my Unseen, and Gardens are my Witnessing,
> And the realities of the new creation are my maidservants.
> If you wish to stroll in my garden,
> You will see all creation in my mirror.
> And when I depart, I am the Imam, and I have no one
> To succeed me who will be behind me.
> So praise be to Allah, Who is the collector
> Of the realities of the Originator and the Origination (الإنشاء).
> This is my poem, reporting wonders
> Whose paths are too narrow for the eloquent.
> So thank our God with me, Abd al-Aziz,
> And also thank the Virgin (العذراء)
> Legally, for Allah said: 'Be grateful to Us
> And to your parents,' and you are the very essence of my decree."

And after praising Allah with the praise of praise, not with anything else, and complete blessings upon the one who was carried by night to his level: Know, O intelligent, cultured, beloved Saint (الولي الحبيب), that when the wise man's home is distant from his counterpart, and the vicissitudes of time intervene between him and his intimate friend, he must inform him of everything he acquired during his absence and the provisions of wisdom (الأمتعة الحكمية) he obtained during his absence. This is to delight his Saintly friend with the subtleties bestowed upon him by the Righteous, the Merciful, and the gifts of gnosis granted to him, the wisdom deposited in him, and the words heard from Him. Thus, his Saintly friend was not absent from him through what he knew of him. Even if the Saint (may Allah preserve him) experienced some clouding of the purity of his affection due to an accident, and some contraction appeared from him at the farewell to complete a purpose, his friend closed the eye of criticism to that and considered it, from the Saint (may Allah preserve him), a noble belief, for only he who asks about you cares about you. So let the Saint (may Allah preserve him) rejoice, for the heart is sound, and affection, as he knows, resides between the ribs. The Saint (may Allah preserve him) already knew that the affection in it was Divine (إليا), not purposeful or egoistic. This was established with him long ago concerning me, without cause, without need for him, without scarcity, without seeking reward, and without fear of punishment.

Perhaps, during the first journey I made to him in the year 590 AH, there was, on the part of the Saint (may Allah preserve him), a lack of attention toward me and an aversion to following my intentions and doctrines, due to the deficiency he observed in me (may Allah be pleased with him). I excused him for that, for the outward state and the textual evidence presented that to him from me. For I concealed from him and his sons what I was upon inwardly (في نفسي) by manifesting to them my poor state and the greed of my senses. Sometimes I would hint to them by way of warning, but Allah refused that any of them should observe me with the eye of transcendence (التنزيه). I once knocked on their ears in an assembly, while the Saint (may Allah preserve him) was seated at the head of that assembly, with verses I recited and deposited in my book *Al-Isra* (The Night Journey):

> I am the Quran and the Seven Oft-Repeated Verses,
> And the Spirit of the Spirit, not the spirit of vessels.
> My heart resides with my Known One,
> Witnessing Him, while my tongue is with you.
> So do not look with your eye toward my body,
> And turn away from enjoying the dwelling places.
> Dive into the sea of the Essence of the Essence (ذات الذات), you will see
> Wonders that have not appeared to sight,
> And secrets (أسرار) that appeared ambiguous,
> Veiled by the spirits of meanings.

By Allah, I did not recite a single verse from this piece except that it was as if I heard it dead. The reason for this was a wisdom whose satisfaction I sought, and a need that Jacob satisfied in his soul. No one in that honored gathering perceived me except Abu Abdullah ibn al-Murabit, their prominent and foremost speaker, but only a partial perception, and confusion (الالتباس) dominated his understanding of my affair. As for the elderly, deceased Shaykh Jarrah, I had unveiled secrets with him concerning an intention in a high Presence. Since leaving the presence of the Saint (may Allah preserve him), I have continuously remembered him, been grateful for his states, spoken of his virtues, and been enamored of his manners. I have sometimes written about this in books that travelers carried and that became famous in some lands. The Saint has seen and reviewed some of what is contained therein. Thus, affection for him was established in me before any cause necessitated it, or any immediate or future purpose established it in the soul and executed it.

Then, the meeting with the Saint (may Allah take charge of him) occurred years later in his most sublime dwelling. The stay with him lasted nine months, lacking only days, in the most comfortable and pleasant life—a life of spirit (روح) and specter (شبح). Each of us was generous with his essence (ذاته) toward his intimate friend and was forgiving. I had a companion, and he had a companion, and both were sincere friends. His companion was a wise, accomplished, regulating Shaykh known as Abu Abdullah ibn al-Murabit, possessing a noble soul, pleasing morals, pure deeds, and commendable qualities. He spent the night in glorification and Quran recitation, and remembered Allah secretly and openly most of the time. A hero in the field of spiritual dealings (المعاملات), understanding what the master of stations (المنازل) and spiritual ascents (المنازلات) brings, fair in his state, distinguishing between what is real and what is impossible. As for my companion, he is pure radiance and sheer light, an Abyssinian named Abdullah Badr (Full Moon), whom no eclipse reaches. He knows the Real (الحق) for its people, delivers it, and restricts it to them without transgression. He attained the degree of distinction (التمييز) and was purified during the assay like refined gold. His speech is truth, and his promise is sincere. Thus, we were the four pillars upon which the person of the World (العالم) and Man (الإنسان) stands. We separated while in this state due to a deviation that arose in some of these places.

For I had intended the Hajj and Umrah, and then to quickly return to his noble assembly. When I reached the Mother of Settlements (Mecca), after visiting the Intimate Friend (Abraham) who established hospitality, and after praying at the Dome of the Rock and Al-Aqsa, and visiting my Master, the Master of the Children of Adam, the Register of Comprehension and Enumeration, Allah established in my mind that I should inform the Saint (may Allah preserve him) of the various gnoses (المعارف) I acquired during my absence, and present to him (may Allah honor him) the jewels of knowledge (جواهر العلم) I obtained during my journey. So I recorded for him this unique treatise, which the Real (الحق) brought into existence as an amulet against the symptoms of ignorance, for every sincere companion and Sufi Realizer (محقق صوفي), and for our beloved Saint, our intelligent brother, and our pleasing son, Abdullah Badr the Abyssinian Yemeni, the freedman of Abu al-Ghanā'im ibn Abi al-Futūh al-Harrani. I named it *The Treatise of the Meccan Revelations (رسالة الفتوحات المكية) concerning the Gnosis of the Royal and Kingly Secrets (الأسرار المالكية والملكية)*, since the majority of what I deposited in this treatise was what Allah disclosed to me during my circumambulation of His honored House or my sitting in contemplation (مراقبا) in His noble, revered Sanctuary.

I made it into noble chapters (أبواب) and deposited subtle meanings (المعاني اللطيفة) within it. For the hardships of the beginning are not made easy for man unless he knows the nobility of the goal, especially if he tastes the sweetness of the fruit thereof and it falls upon him in the place of desire. If the chapter restricts the sight, the eye of the wise man's insight (بصيرة الحكيم) will turn to it, and he will look and extract pearls and gems. The chapter will then grant him the spiritual wisdom (حكم روحانية) and Divine points (نكت ربانية) it contains, according to the extent of his penetration, his understanding, the strength of his resolve, his imagination, and the breadth of his soul due to his diving into the depths of the seas of his knowledge.

> When I adhered to knocking at the door of Allah,
> I was the Contemplator (المراقب), I was not heedless.
> Until the radiance of His Face appeared to the eye,
> And to 'Come hither,' there was nothing but it.
> So I encompassed Existence (الوجود) with knowledge, for we have
> In our heart no knowledge but of Allah.
> If the strange creation were to follow my path,
> They would not ask you what the Realities (الحقائق) are.

Therefore, before commencing the discourse on the chapters (أبواب) of this book, let us present a chapter on the index of its chapters, followed by an introduction to pave the way for the esoteric Divine Sciences (العلوم الإلهية الإسرارية) contained in this book. Following that, the discourse on the chapters will proceed according to their arrangement in the index chapter, if Allah wills. <<وَاللَّهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way). End of the First Volume. Praise be to Allah. The Second Volume follows, if Allah wills. And may Allah bless Muhammad and his pure family.

In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful.

### Chapter on the Index of the Book's Chapters (فهرست أبواب الكتاب)

(Which is not counted among the chapters, and which consists of six sections)

### Section One: Concerning Gnosis (المعارف)

Chapter One: Concerning the Gnosis (معرفة) of the Spirit (الروح) from whose detailed origination I have written what is recorded in this book, and the secrets (الأسرار) that passed between me and it.
Chapter Two: Concerning the Gnosis of the Levels (مراتب) of the Letters and Vowelizations in the World (العالم), and the Beautiful Names (الأسماء الحسنى) pertaining to them, and the Gnosis of the words that suggest similitude (التشبيه), and the Gnosis of Knowledge (العلم), the Knower (العالم), and the Known (المعلوم).
Chapter Three: Concerning the Transcendence (تنزيه) of the Real (الحق) from the similitude (التشبيه) and corporeality (التجسيم) contained within the words applied to Him in His Book and upon the tongue of His Messenger (peace be upon him).
Chapter Four: Concerning the reason for the beginning and origination of the World (العالم), and the Levels (مراتب) of the Beautiful Names in the World.
Chapter Five: Concerning the Gnosis of the secrets (أسرار) of *Bismillah al-Rahman al-Rahim* from one perspective, not from all its aspects.
Chapter Six: Concerning the Gnosis of the beginning of the spiritual creation (الخلق الروحاني), who is the first existent therein, from what he came into existence, in what he came into existence, upon what likeness he came into existence, and why he came into existence; and the Gnosis of the spheres of the Greater and Lesser World (العالم الأكبر والأصغر).
Chapter Seven: Concerning the Gnosis of the beginning of human bodies (الجسوم الإنسانية), which is the last existent of the Greater World.
Chapter Eight: Concerning the Gnosis of the Earth created from the remainder of the leaven of Adam's clay (طينة آدم), and the wonders and marvels within it, called the Earth of Reality (أرض الحقيقة).
Chapter Nine: Concerning the Gnosis of the existence of the fiery, smokeless spirits (الأرواح النارية المارجية).
Chapter Ten: Concerning the Gnosis of the cycle of the King, the first thing separated therein from the first existent, and the last thing separated therein from the last thing separated from it, and by what the separated place from both of them was inhabited, and Allah's preparation of this dominion until its King arrived, and the level (مرتبة) of the World between Jesus (peace be upon him) and Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him).
Chapter Eleven: Concerning the Gnosis of our celestial fathers (آبائنا العلويات) and our terrestrial mothers (أمهاتنا السفليات).
Chapter Twelve: Concerning the Gnosis of the cycle of the Master of the World, Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), and that time in his era revolved to its form on the day Allah created it.
Chapter Thirteen: Concerning the Gnosis of the Bearers of the Throne (حملة العرش): Israfil, Adam, Michael, Abraham, Gabriel, Muhammad, Ridwan, and Malik (peace be upon them).
Chapter Fourteen: Concerning the Gnosis of the secrets (أسرار) of the tidings of the Saints (الأولياء) and the Poles (أقطاب) of the nations from Adam to Muhammad (peace be upon them both), and that the Pole is one since Allah created him, he has not died, and where his dwelling is.
Chapter Fifteen: Concerning the Gnosis of the Breaths (الأنفاس) and the Gnosis of their Realizing Poles (أقطابها المحققين) and their secrets.

Chapter Seventeen: Concerning the Gnosis of the transmission of the cosmic sciences and a portion of the original supporting Divine Sciences (العلوم الإلهية الممدة الأصلية).
Chapter Eighteen: Concerning the Gnosis of the science of those who keep vigil (علم المتهجدين), the issues related to it, its measure in the levels of sciences, and what manifests from it of the sciences in cosmic existence.

### Section Five: The Divine Communications (الفصل الخامس في المنازلات)

(Chapter 384) Concerning the Knowledge of the Communicative Divine Communications (al-Munazalat al-Khitabiyya), and it is from the secret of His saying, the Exalted: <<It is not for any human being that Allah should speak to him except by revelation (wahyan) or from behind a veil (hijab)>> [Quran 42:51], and it is from the Muhammadan Presence
(Chapter 385) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who is belittled is overcome, and he who is scorned is prevented
(Chapter 386) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: The Jugular Vein (Habl al-Warid) and the "Whereness" (Ayniyyat) of Companionship (Maʿiyya)
(Chapter 387) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: Majestic Humility (al-Tawaduʿ al-Kibriya’i)
(Chapter 388) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication Unknown to the Servant, which is when he ascends without specifying the object of his intention from the Real (al-Haqq)
(Chapter 389) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: "To Me is your being (kawnuka), and to you is My being (kawni)"
(Chapter 390) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: The time (zaman) of a thing is its existence (wujud), except for Me, for I have no time, and except for you, for you have no time; so you are My time, and I am your time
(Chapter 391) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: The Flowing Path (al-Maslak al-Sayyal) upon which the Men of Asking (Rijal al-Su’al) cannot stand firm
(Chapter 392) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who shows mercy, We show him mercy; and he who does not show mercy, We show him mercy, then We become angry with him and forget him
(Chapter 393) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who pauses when seeing what terrifies him is destroyed
(Chapter 394) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who observes proper conduct (ta’addab) arrives, and he who arrives does not return, even if he was not observant of proper conduct
(Chapter 395) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who enters My Presence (Hadra) while his life remains upon him, his consolation for the death of his companion is upon Me
(Chapter 396) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who gathers gnoses (maʿarif) and sciences (ʿulum), I veil him from Me
(Chapter 397) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: <<To Him ascends the good word, and the righteous deed elevates it>> [Quran 35:10]
(Chapter 398) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who preaches to people does not know Me, and he who reminds them knows Me
(Chapter 399) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: The Stage (Manzil) of him who enters it, his neck is struck, and no one remains but enters it
(Chapter 400) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who manifests to Me, I am hidden from him; and he who stands at My boundary, I look upon him
(Chapter 401) Concerning the Divine Communication: The dead and the living have no path to My Vision
(Chapter 402) Concerning the Divine Communication: He who overcomes Me, I overcome him; and he whom I overcome, overcomes Me; thus, inclining toward peace (silm) is better
(Chapter 403) Concerning the Divine Communication: I have no argument against My servants; I never said to one of them, "Why did you do this?" but he said to Me, "You did it." And the Real (al-Haqq) spoke truly, but the Precedence (Sabiqa) is more precedent, and there is no changing
(Chapter 404) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who is harsh toward his subjects strives for the destruction of his kingdom, and he who is gentle with them remains a king. Every master who kills a servant from among his servants has only killed a lordship from his own lordship, except for Me—so reflect
(Chapter 405) Concerning the Divine Communication: He who makes his heart My House and empties it of all but Me, no one knows what I give him. So do not liken it to the Frequented House (al-Bayt al-Maʿmur), for that is the house of My angels, not My House. For this reason, I did not settle My Intimate Friend (Khalil) therein. Rather, My House is the heart of My servant, which contained Me when My earth and My heaven were too narrow for Me
(Chapter 406) Concerning the Divine Communication: Nothing has ever manifested from Me to anything, nor is it fitting that it should manifest
(Chapter 407) Concerning the Divine Communication: Faster than the blink of an eye, you are snatched away from Me if you look at other than Me—not due to My weakness, but due to your weakness
(Chapter 408) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: The Day of Saturday (Yawm al-Sabt). So loosen the apron of seriousness (jidd) that you have tightened, for the World has been emptied of Me, and I have been emptied of it
(Chapter 409) Concerning the Divine Communication: My Names (Asma’) are a veil (hijab) upon you; if you lift them, you reach Me
(Chapter 410) Concerning the Divine Communication: <<And that to your Lord is the final end (al-Muntaha)>> [Quran 53:42]. So take pride in this Lord, and you will be felicitous
(Chapter 411) Concerning the Divine Communication: The Book (Kitab) precedes him, so he enters the Fire from a Presence (Hadra) where he almost did not enter the Fire. So fear the Book, and do not fear Me, for I and you are equal
(Chapter 412) Concerning the Divine Communication: He who is for Me will never be humiliated or disgraced
(Chapter 413) Concerning the Divine Communication: He who asks Me has not departed from My Decree (Qada’), and he who does not ask Me has not departed from My Decree
(Chapter 414) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: We are not seen except by a veil (hijab)
(Chapter 415) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who calls upon Me has fulfilled the due of his servitude (ʿubudiyya), and he who is fair to himself has been fair to Me
(Chapter 416) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: The Eye of the Heart (ʿAyn al-Qalb)
(Chapter 417) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He whose reward is upon Allah
(Chapter 418) Concerning the Divine Communication: He who does not understand, nothing reaches him
(Chapter 419) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: The Deeds/Documents (al-Sukuk)
(Chapter 420) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: Escaping from the Stations (Maqamat)
(Chapter 421) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who seeks to reach Me through the path of proof (dalil) and demonstration (burhan) will never reach Me, for nothing resembles Me
(Chapter 422) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who refers My Act (Fiʿl) back to Me has given Me My due
(Chapter 423) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who is zealous for Me (Ghira ʿalayya) does not mention Me
(Chapter 424) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: I love you for your remaining with Me, but you love to return to your people. So stop until I am satisfied with you, and then you may pass away from Me
(Chapter 425) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who seeks knowledge (ʿilm), I turn his gaze away from Me
(Chapter 426) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: The Secret (Sirr) from which he (peace be upon him) spoke when he was asked about seeing his Lord, and he said, "Light (Nur). Indeed, I see it."
(Chapter 427) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: <<Two Bow-Lengths>> (Qaba Qawsayn) [Quran 53:9]
(Chapter 428) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: The Interrogation concerning the Two Signs (Ayatayn)
(Chapter 429) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who humbles himself before My Majesty (Jalal), I descend to him; and he who acts proudly toward Me, I act proudly toward him
(Chapter 430) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: That your Bewilderment (Hayra) has brought you to Me
(Chapter 431) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He whom I veil, I veil him
(Chapter 432) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: I have not adorned Myself with anything except you, so know your worth. And here is the wonder: a thing that does not know itself
(Chapter 433) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: Look for which Theophany (Tajalli) annihilates you, and do not ask Me for it, lest We give it to you and I find no one to take it
(Chapter 434) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: Do not let Him veil you, if you wish, for I do not wish yet, so stand firm
(Chapter 435) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: I took a covenant upon Myself, and at times I fulfilled it, and at times I did not fulfill it, so do not object
(Chapter 436) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: If you were with people as you are with Me, they would not worship Me
(Chapter 437) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who knows his portion of My Law (Shariʿa) knows his portion of Me, for you are with Me as I am with you, one single degree (martaba)
(Chapter 438) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who reads My Speech (Kalam) sees a cloud (ghamma) in which the lamps of My angels descend upon him and into him; but when he falls silent, they depart from him, and I descend
(Chapter 439) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: The Second <<Two Bow-Lengths>> (Qaba Qawsayn)
(Chapter 440) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: A pillar of his heart’s strength was intensified by My Witnessing (Mushahada)
(Chapter 441) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: The eyes of the hearts (af’ida) of the Gnostics (ʿArifin) are looking toward what is with Me, not toward Me
(Chapter 442) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who sees Me and knows that he has seen Me has not seen Me
(Chapter 443) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: The Obligation of Gnostic Unveiling (Wajib al-Kashf al-ʿIrfani)
(Chapter 444) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He for whom I write the Book of Pure Covenant (Kitab al-ʿAhd al-Khalis) will not be wretched
(Chapter 445) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: Have you known My Saints (Awliya’) whom I disciplined with My Proper Conduct (Adab)?
(Chapter 446) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: In the cultivation of the night’s beginnings (nawashi’ al-layl) are the benefits of goodness (khayrat)
(Chapter 447) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who enters the Presence of Purification (Hadrat al-Tathir) speaks on My behalf
(Chapter 448) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He to whom I unveil something of what is with Me is stunned, so how can he seek to see Me?
(Chapter 449) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: My servant is not he who worships My servant
(Chapter 450) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who stands firm before My Manifestation (Zuhur) is by Me, not by himself—Glory be to Me—he is by himself, not by Me. This is the Reality (Haqiqa), and the former is metaphor (Majaz)
(Chapter 451) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: In the Exits (Makharij) is the Knowledge of the Ascents (Maʿarij)
(Chapter 452) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: All My Speech (Kalam) is an admonition (mawʿiza) for My servants, if only they would take heed
(Chapter 453) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: My Nobility (Karam) is what I expend upon you of wealth, and the Nobility of My Nobility is what I grant you of your forgiveness toward your brother when he wrongs you
(Chapter 454) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: No stranger (gharib) can be strong with Us in Our Presence (Hadra); rather, the favor (maʿruf) is for those nearest in kinship (Uli al-Qurba)
(Chapter 455) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He toward whom I turn with My Outward Aspect (Zahiri) will never be felicitous, and he toward whom I turn with My Inward Aspect (Batini) will never be wretched—and vice versa
(Chapter 456) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He who stirs upon hearing My Speech (Kalam) has truly heard
(Chapter 457) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: Absolute Imposition of Duty (al-Taklif al-Mutlaq)
(Chapter 458) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: Attaining the Glories (Subuhat)
(Chapter 459) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: <<And indeed, with Us they are among the chosen, the excellent>> [Quran 38:47]
(Chapter 460) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: Submission (Islam), Faith (Iman), Excellence (Ihsan), and the Excellence of Excellence (Ihsan al-Ihsan)
(Chapter 461) Concerning the Knowledge of the Divine Communication: He upon whom I let down the veil (hijab) of My Negation (Nafy) is one of My Intimates (Dana’ini); no one knows him, and he knows no one

### Section Six: The Stations (الفصل السادس في المقامات)

(Chapter 462) In knowing the Muhammadan Poles (الأقطاب المحمديون) and their stations (منازلهم).
(Chapter 463) In knowing the Twelve Poles, who are those around whom the sphere of the World (العالم) revolves.
