(Chapter 465) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: *Allāhu Akbar* (Allah is Greater).
(Chapter 466) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: *Subḥāna Allāh* (Glory be to Allah).
(Chapter 467) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: *Al-Ḥamdu li-Llāh* (Praise be to Allah).
(Chapter 468) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: *Al-Ḥamdu li-Llāh ‘alā kulli ḥāl* (Praise be to Allah in every state).
(Chapter 469) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<أُفَوِّضُ أَمْرِي إِلَى الله>> (I entrust my affair to Allah).
(Chapter 470) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وما خَلَقْتُ الْجِنَّ والْإِنْسَ إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُونِ>> (And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me).
(Chapter 471) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<قُلْ إِنْ كُنْتُمْ تُحِبُّونَ الله فَاتَّبِعُونِي يُحْبِبْكُمُ الله>> (Say: If you love Allah, then follow me, [and] Allah will love you).
(Chapter 472) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<فَبَشِّرْ عِبادِ الَّذِينَ يَسْتَمِعُونَ الْقَوْلَ فَيَتَّبِعُونَ أَحْسَنَهُ>> (So give good tidings to My servants who listen to the Word and follow the best of it).
(Chapter 473) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وإِلهُكُمْ إِلهٌ واحِدٌ>> (And your God is one God).
(Chapter 474) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ما عِنْدَكُمْ يَنْفَدُ وما عِنْدَ الله باقٍ>> (What is with you is exhausted, but what is with Allah remains).
(Chapter 475) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ومن يُعَظِّمْ شَعائِرَ الله فَإِنَّها من تَقْوَى الْقُلُوبِ>> (And whoever honors the symbols of Allah—indeed, it is from the piety of hearts).
(Chapter 476) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<فَلَمَّا تَبَيَّنَ لَهُ أَنَّهُ عَدُوٌّ لِلَّهِ تَبَرَّأَ مِنْهُ>> (But when it became clear to him that he was an enemy of Allah, he disassociated himself from him). The power and strength belong to Allah; there is no might nor power except by Allah.
(Chapter 477) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وفي ذلِكَ فَلْيَتَنافَسِ الْمُتَنافِسُونَ لِمِثْلِ هذا فَلْيَعْمَلِ الْعامِلُونَ>> (And for that let the competitors compete. For the like of this, let the workers work).
(Chapter 478) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<إِنْ تَكُ مِثْقالَ حَبَّةٍ من خَرْدَلٍ فَتَكُنْ في صَخْرَةٍ أَوْ في السَّماواتِ أَوْ في الْأَرْضِ يَأْتِ بِهَا الله إِنَّ الله لَطِيفٌ خَبِيرٌ>> (Even if it should be the weight of a mustard seed and it be in a rock or [anywhere] in the heavens or in the earth, Allah will bring it forth. Indeed, Allah is Subtle, All-Aware).
(Chapter 479) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ومن يُعَظِّمْ حُرُماتِ الله فَهُوَ خَيْرٌ لَهُ عِنْدَ رَبِّهِ>> (And whoever honors the sacred things of Allah—it is better for him in the sight of his Lord). Roll up your sleeves, for the matter is serious.
(Chapter 480) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وآتَيْناهُ الْحُكْمَ صَبِيًّا>> (And We gave him judgment [i.e., wisdom] while he was a child).
(Chapter 481) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<إن الله لا يضيع أَجْرَ من أَحْسَنَ عَمَلًا>> (Indeed, Allah does not allow to be lost the reward of those who do good in deed).
(Chapter 482) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ومن يُسْلِمْ وَجْهَهُ إِلَى الله وهُوَ مُحْسِنٌ فَقَدِ اسْتَمْسَكَ بِالْعُرْوَةِ الْوُثْقى‏ وإِلَى الله عاقِبَةُ الْأُمُورِ>> (And whoever submits his face to Allah while he is a doer of good has grasped the most trustworthy handhold. And to Allah belongs the outcome of [all] matters).
(Chapter 483) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<قَدْ أَفْلَحَ من زَكَّاها وقَدْ خابَ من دَسَّاها>> (He has succeeded who purifies it, and he has failed who covers it [with sin]).
(Chapter 484) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<فَلَوْ لا إِذا بَلَغَتِ الْحُلْقُومَ وأَنْتُمْ حِينَئِذٍ تَنْظُرُونَ>> (Then why, when the soul reaches the throat and you are at that time looking on).
(Chapter 485) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<من كانَ يُرِيدُ الْحَياةَ الدُّنْيا وزِينَتَها نُوَفِّ إِلَيْهِمْ أَعْمالَهُمْ فِيها وهُمْ فِيها لا يُبْخَسُونَ>> (Whoever desires the life of this world and its adornments—We fully repay them for their deeds therein, and they will not be deprived of it).
(Chapter 486) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ومن يَعْصِ الله ورَسُولَهُ فَقَدْ ضَلَّ ضَلالًا مُبِيناً>> (And whoever disobeys Allah and His Messenger has certainly strayed into clear error).
(Chapter 487) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<من عَمِلَ صالِحاً من ذَكَرٍ أَوْ أُنْثى‏ وهُوَ مُؤْمِنٌ فَلَنُحْيِيَنَّهُ حَياةً طَيِّبَةً>> (Whoever does righteousness, whether male or female, while he is a believer—We will surely cause him to live a good life).
(Chapter 488) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ولا تَمُدَّنَّ عَيْنَيْكَ إِلى‏ ما مَتَّعْنا به أَزْواجاً مِنْهُمْ زَهْرَةَ الْحَياةِ الدُّنْيا لِنَفْتِنَهُمْ فِيهِ ورِزْقُ رَبِّكَ خَيْرٌ وأَبْقى‏>> (And do not extend your eyes toward that by which We have given enjoyment to [various] kinds of them—the splendor of worldly life—that We may test them thereby. But the provision of your Lord is better and more lasting).
(Chapter 489) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<أَنَّما أَمْوالُكُمْ وأَوْلادُكُمْ فِتْنَةٌ>> (That your wealth and your children are but a trial [fitnah]).
(Chapter 490) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<كَبُرَ مَقْتاً عِنْدَ الله أَنْ تَقُولُوا ما لا تَفْعَلُونَ>> (Great is hatred in the sight of Allah that you say what you do not do).
(Chapter 491) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<لا تَفْرَحْ إِنَّ الله لا يُحِبُّ الْفَرِحِينَ>> (Do not rejoice. Indeed, Allah does not like the joyful).
(Chapter 492) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<عالِمُ الْغَيْبِ فَلا يُظْهِرُ عَلى‏ غَيْبِهِ أَحَداً إِلَّا من ارْتَضى‏ من رَسُولٍ>> (Knower of the Unseen (الغيب), and He does not disclose His Unseen to anyone, except to a messenger whom He has approved).
(Chapter 493) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<قُلْ كُلٌّ من عِنْدِ الله فَما لِهؤُلاءِ الْقَوْمِ لا يَكادُونَ يَفْقَهُونَ حَدِيثاً>> (Say, "All is from Allah." So what is [the matter] with these people that they hardly understand any statement?).
(Chapter 494) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<إِنَّما يَخْشَى الله من عِبادِهِ الْعُلَماءُ>> (Only those fear Allah, from among His servants, who have Knowledge [al-’Ulamā’]).
(Chapter 495) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ومن يَرْتَدِدْ مِنْكُمْ عَنْ دِينِهِ فَيَمُتْ وهُوَ كافِرٌ>> (And whoever of you reverts from his religion and dies while he is a disbeliever).
(Chapter 496) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وما قَدَرُوا الله حَقَّ قَدْرِهِ وجاهِدُوا في الله حَقَّ جِهادِهِ>> (And they did not appraise Allah with true appraisal... and strive for Allah with the striving due to Him).
(Chapter 497) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وما يُؤْمِنُ أَكْثَرُهُمْ بِاللَّهِ إِلَّا وهُمْ مُشْرِكُونَ>> (And most of them do not believe in Allah except while they associate others with Him).
(Chapter 498) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ومن يَتَّقِ الله يَجْعَلْ لَهُ مَخْرَجاً>> (And whoever fears Allah—He will make for him a way out).
(Chapter 499) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him).
(Chapter 500) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ومن يَقُلْ مِنْهُمْ إِنِّي إِلهٌ من دُونِهِ فَذلِكَ نَجْزِيهِ جَهَنَّمَ>> (And whoever among them should say, "Indeed, I am a god besides Him"—that one We would recompense with Hell).
(Chapter 501) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<أَ غَيْرَ الله تَدْعُونَ إِنْ كُنْتُمْ صادِقِينَ>> (Is it other than Allah you call upon, if you should be truthful?).
(Chapter 502) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<لا تَخُونُوا الله والرَّسُولَ وتَخُونُوا أَماناتِكُمْ وأَنْتُمْ تَعْلَمُونَ>> (Do not betray Allah and the Messenger or betray your trusts while you know [the consequence]).
(Chapter 503) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وما أُمِرُوا إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُوا الله مُخْلِصِينَ لَهُ الدِّينَ حُنَفاءَ>> (And they were not commanded except to worship Allah, [being] sincere to Him in religion, inclining to truth [ḥunafā’]).
(Chapter 504) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<قُلِ الله ثُمَّ ذَرْهُمْ في خَوْضِهِمْ يَلْعَبُونَ>> (Say, "Allah." Then leave them in their [false] discourse, playing).
(Chapter 505) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<واصْبِرْ لِحُكْمِ رَبِّكَ فَإِنَّكَ بِأَعْيُنِنا>> (And be patient for the decision of your Lord, for indeed, you are in Our eyes).
(Chapter 506) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ومَكَرُوا ومَكَرَ الله والله خَيْرُ الْماكِرِينَ>> (And they planned, and Allah planned. And Allah is the best of planners).
(Chapter 507) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<أَ لَمْ يَعْلَمْ بِأَنَّ الله يَرى‏>> (Does he not know that Allah sees?).
(Chapter 508) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<الله وَلِيُّ الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا يُخْرِجُهُمْ من الظُّلُماتِ إِلَى النُّورِ>> (Allah is the Protector (Walī) of those who believe. He brings them out from darknesses into the light).
(Chapter 509) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وما أَنْفَقْتُمْ من شَيْءٍ فَهُوَ يُخْلِفُهُ وهُوَ خَيْرُ الرَّازِقِينَ>> (But whatever thing you spend [in His cause]—He will compensate it; and He is the best of providers).
(Chapter 510) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<سَأَصْرِفُ عَنْ آياتِيَ الَّذِينَ يَتَكَبَّرُونَ في الْأَرْضِ بِغَيْرِ الْحَقِّ>> (I will turn away from My signs those who are arrogant upon the earth without right).
(Chapter 511) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<واتَّقُوا الله ويُعَلِّمُكُمُ الله إِنْ تَتَّقُوا الله يَجْعَلْ لَكُمْ فُرْقاناً>> (And fear Allah, and Allah teaches you. If you fear Allah, He will grant you a criterion [furqān]).
(Chapter 512) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<كُلَّما نَضِجَتْ جُلُودُهُمْ بَدَّلْناهُمْ جُلُوداً غَيْرَها لِيَذُوقُوا الْعَذابَ>> (Whenever their skins are roasted through, We will replace them with other skins so they may taste the punishment).
(Chapter 513) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ذِكْرُ رَحْمَتِ رَبِّكَ عَبْدَهُ زَكَرِيَّا إِذْ نادى‏ رَبَّهُ نِداءً خَفِيًّا>> (A mention of the mercy of your Lord to His servant Zechariah, when he called out to his Lord a private supplication).
(Chapter 514) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ومن يَتَوَكَّلْ عَلَى الله فَهُوَ حَسْبُهُ>> (And whoever relies upon Allah—then He is sufficient for him).
(Chapter 515) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وظَنَّ داوُدُ أَنَّما فَتَنَّاهُ فَاسْتَغْفَرَ رَبَّهُ وخَرَّ راكِعاً وأَنابَ>> (And David realized that We had tried him, so he sought forgiveness from his Lord and fell down bowing [in prostration] and repented).
(Chapter 516) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<قُلْ إِنْ كانَ آباؤُكُمْ وأَبْناؤُكُمْ وإِخْوانُكُمْ وأَزْواجُكُمْ وعَشِيرَتُكُمْ وأَمْوالٌ اقْتَرَفْتُمُوها وتِجارَةٌ تَخْشَوْنَ كَسادَها ومَساكِنُ تَرْضَوْنَها أَحَبَّ إِلَيْكُمْ من الله ورَسُولِهِ وجِهادٍ في سَبِيلِهِ فَتَرَبَّصُوا حَتَّى يَأْتِيَ الله بِأَمْرِهِ فَفِرُّوا إِلَى الله>> (Say, [O Muhammad], "If your fathers, your sons, your brothers, your wives, your relatives, wealth which you have gained, commerce wherein you fear decline, and dwellings with which you are pleased are more beloved to you than Allah and His Messenger and striving in His cause, then wait until Allah executes His command." So flee to Allah).
(Chapter 517) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<حَتَّى إِذا ضاقَتْ عَلَيْهِمُ الْأَرْضُ بِما رَحُبَتْ وضاقَتْ عَلَيْهِمْ أَنْفُسُهُمْ وظَنُّوا أَنْ لا مَلْجَأَ من الله إِلَّا إِلَيْهِ>> (Until, when the earth had become restricted for them despite its vastness, and their souls became restricted for them, and they realized that there is no refuge from Allah except in Him).
(Chapter 518) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<حَتَّى إِذا فُزِّعَ عَنْ قُلُوبِهِمْ قالُوا ما ذا قالَ رَبُّكُمْ قالُوا الْحَقَّ وهُوَ الْعَلِيُّ الْكَبِيرُ>> (Until, when terror is removed from their hearts, they will say, "What did your Lord say?" They will say, "The Truth (al-Ḥaqq)." And He is the Most High, the Grand).
(Chapter 519) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<اسْتَجِيبُوا لِلَّهِ ولِلرَّسُولِ إِذا دَعاكُمْ لِما يُحْيِيكُمْ واعْلَمُوا أَنَّ الله يَحُولُ بَيْنَ الْمَرْءِ وقَلْبِهِ وأَنَّهُ إِلَيْهِ تُحْشَرُونَ>> (Respond to Allah and to the Messenger when he calls you to that which gives you life. And know that Allah intervenes between a man and his heart and that to Him you will be gathered).
(Chapter 520) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<إِنَّما يَسْتَجِيبُ الَّذِينَ يَسْمَعُونَ>> (Only those who hear will respond).
(Chapter 521) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وتَزَوَّدُوا فَإِنَّ خَيْرَ الزَّادِ التَّقْوى‏ واتَّقُونِ>> (And take provision, but indeed, the best provision is piety (al-Taqwā). And fear Me).
(Chapter 522) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<والَّذِينَ يُؤْتُونَ ما آتَوْا وقُلُوبُهُمْ وَجِلَةٌ أَنَّهُمْ إِلى‏ رَبِّهِمْ راجِعُونَ أُولئِكَ يُسارِعُونَ في الْخَيْراتِ وهُمْ لَها سابِقُونَ>> (And those who give what they give while their hearts are fearful because they will be returning to their Lord—it is those who hasten to good deeds, and they are the foremost in [achieving] them).
(Chapter 523) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وأَمَّا من خافَ مَقامَ رَبِّهِ>> (But as for he who feared the standing before his Lord).
(Chapter 524) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<قُلْ لَوْ كانَ الْبَحْرُ مِداداً لِكَلِماتِ رَبِّي لَنَفِدَ الْبَحْرُ قَبْلَ أَنْ تَنْفَدَ كَلِماتُ رَبِّي ولَوْ جِئْنا بِمِثْلِهِ مَدَداً>> (Say, "If the sea were ink for the words of my Lord, the sea would be exhausted before the words of my Lord were exhausted, even if We brought the like of it as a supplement").
(Chapter 525) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ومن يَتَعَدَّ حُدُودَ الله فَقَدْ ظَلَمَ نَفْسَهُ لا تَدْرِي لَعَلَّ الله يُحْدِثُ بَعْدَ ذلِكَ أَمْراً>> (And whoever transgresses the limits of Allah has certainly wronged himself. You do not know; perhaps Allah will bring about after that a [different] matter).
(Chapter 526) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<ولَوْ لا أَنْ ثَبَّتْناكَ لَقَدْ كِدْتَ تَرْكَنُ إِلَيْهِمْ شَيْئاً قَلِيلًا إِذاً لَأَذَقْناكَ ضِعْفَ الْحَياةِ وضِعْفَ الْمَماتِ>> (And if We had not strengthened you, you would have almost inclined to them slightly. Then [if you had], We would have made you taste double [punishment in] life and double [after] death).
(Chapter 527) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<واصْبِرْ نَفْسَكَ مَعَ الَّذِينَ يَدْعُونَ رَبَّهُمْ بِالْغَداةِ والْعَشِيِّ يُرِيدُونَ وَجْهَهُ ولا تَعْدُ عَيْناكَ عَنْهُمْ تُرِيدُ زِينَةَ الْحَياةِ الدُّنْيا ولا تُطِعْ من أَغْفَلْنا قَلْبَهُ عَنْ ذِكْرِنا واتَّبَعَ هَواهُ وكانَ أَمْرُهُ فُرُطاً وقُلِ الْحَقُّ من رَبِّكُمْ فَمَنْ شاءَ فَلْيُؤْمِنْ ومن شاءَ فَلْيَكْفُرْ>> (And keep yourself patient [by being] with those who call upon their Lord in the morning and the evening, desiring His Face. And let not your eyes pass beyond them, desiring the adornments of the worldly life. And do not obey one whose heart We have made heedless of Our remembrance and who follows his desire and whose affair is [ever] in excess. And say, "The Truth (al-Ḥaqq) is from your Lord," so whoever wills—let him believe; and whoever wills—let him disbelieve).
(Chapter 528) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وجَزاءُ سَيِّئَةٍ سَيِّئَةٌ مِثْلُها>> (And the recompense of an evil deed is an evil deed like it).
(Chapter 529) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<والْبَلَدُ الطَّيِّبُ يَخْرُجُ نَباتُهُ بِإِذْنِ رَبِّهِ والَّذِي خَبُثَ لا يَخْرُجُ إِلَّا نَكِداً>> (The good land—its vegetation emerges by permission of its Lord; but that which is bad—nothing comes out except sparsely).
(Chapter 530) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<يَسْتَخْفُونَ من النَّاسِ ولا يَسْتَخْفُونَ من الله وهُوَ مَعَهُمْ إِذْ يُبَيِّتُونَ ما لا يَرْضى‏ من الْقَوْلِ>> (They conceal [their evil intentions] from the people, but they cannot conceal them from Allah, and He is with them when they plot during the night [with] what displeases [Him] of speech).
(Chapter 531) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وما تَكُونُ في شَأْنٍ وما تَتْلُوا مِنْهُ من قُرْآنٍ ولا تَعْمَلُونَ من عَمَلٍ إِلَّا كُنَّا عَلَيْكُمْ شُهُوداً إِذْ تُفِيضُونَ فِيهِ>> (And you are not [engaged] in any matter or recite any portion of the Qur’an or do any deed except that We are witnesses over you when you are involved in it).
(Chapter 532) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<إِنَّ الصَّلاةَ كانَتْ عَلَى الْمُؤْمِنِينَ كِتاباً مَوْقُوتاً>> (Indeed, prayer has been decreed upon the believers at fixed times).
(Chapter 533) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وإِذا سَأَلَكَ عِبادِي عَنِّي فَإِنِّي قَرِيبٌ أُجِيبُ دَعْوَةَ الدَّاعِ إِذا دَعانِ فَلْيَسْتَجِيبُوا لِي>> (And when My servants ask you concerning Me—indeed, I am near. I respond to the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me. So let them respond to Me).
(Chapter 534) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وإِنَّكَ لَعَلى‏ خُلُقٍ عَظِيمٍ>> (And indeed, you are upon a great character).
(Chapter 535) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<الَّذِينَ يَذْكُرُونَ الله قِياماً وقُعُوداً وعَلى‏ جُنُوبِهِمْ>> (Those who remember Allah while standing or sitting or [lying] on their sides).
(Chapter 536) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<من كانَ يُرِيدُ حَرْثَ الدُّنْيا نُؤْتِهِ مِنْها وما لَهُ في الْآخِرَةِ من نَصِيبٍ>> (Whoever desires the harvest of this world—We give him thereof, but he has no share in the Hereafter).
(Chapter 537) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<وتَخْشَى النَّاسَ والله أَحَقُّ أَنْ تَخْشاهُ>> (And you feared the people, while Allah is more worthy that you fear Him).
(Chapter 538) In knowing the state of a Pole whose station was: <<فَاسْتَقِمْ كَما أُمِرْتَ ومن تابَ مَعَكَ ولا تَطْغَوْا إِنَّهُ بِما تَعْمَلُونَ بَصِيرٌ>> (So remain on a straight course as you have been commanded, [you] and those who have repented with you, and do not transgress. ### Introduction

### [Ranks of Knowledge (مراتب العلوم)]

We said that perhaps it occurred to me to place a chapter in this book first concerning doctrines (العقائد) supported by decisive proofs (الأدلة القاطعة) and brilliant demonstrations (البراهين الساطعة). Then I saw that this would distract the prepared seeker (المتأهب) who desires increase and exposes himself to the breaths of generosity (نفحات الجود) through the secrets of Being (أسرار الوجود). For when the prepared seeker adheres to retreat (الخلوة) and remembrance (الذكر), and empties the vessel (المحل) of thought (الفكر), sitting poor and possessing nothing at the door of his Lord, then Allah the Exalted grants him and gives him of the Knowledge of Him, the Divine Secrets (الأسرار الإلهية), and the Lordly Gnosis (المعارف الربانية), which Allah the Glorious praised His servant Khidr for possessing, saying: <<عَبْداً من عِبادِنا آتَيْناهُ رَحْمَةً من عِنْدِنا وعَلَّمْناهُ من لَدُنَّا عِلْماً>> (A servant from among Our servants to whom We had given mercy from Us and whom We had taught knowledge from Our own Presence [ladunnā]). And the Exalted said: <<واتَّقُوا الله ويُعَلِّمُكُمُ الله>> (And fear Allah, and Allah teaches you). And He said: <<إِنْ تَتَّقُوا الله يَجْعَلْ لَكُمْ فُرْقاناً>> (If you fear Allah, He will grant you a criterion [furqān]). And He said: <<ويَجْعَلْ لَكُمْ نُوراً تَمْشُونَ به>> (And He will make for you a light by which you walk).

Junayd was asked how he attained what he attained, and he replied: "By sitting beneath that step for thirty years." Abu Yazid said: "You took your knowledge from the dead concerning the dead, but we took our knowledge from the Living Who never dies."

Thus, the person of high spiritual aspiration (صاحب الهمة) in retreat with Allah—glorious is His gift and immense is His favor—attains knowledge before which every speaker on the face of the earth, indeed, every person of rational speculation (صاحب نظر وبرهان) who lacks this state, is eclipsed. This is because [this knowledge] is beyond the sphere of the intellect (طور العقل), since knowledge is of three ranks (مراتب):

1. **Knowledge of the Intellect (علم العقل):** This is all knowledge attained necessarily (ضرورة) or following speculation (نظر) based on a proof (دليل), provided one discovers the aspect of that proof and its likeness within the realm of thought (عالم الفكر) that gathers and specializes in this type of knowledge. This is why they say that speculation yields both sound and corrupt results.

2. **Knowledge of States (علم الأحوال):** There is no path to this except through direct experience (الذوق). No rational person can define it or establish a proof for its recognition, such as the knowledge of the sweetness of honey, the bitterness of patience, the pleasure of intercourse, love (العشق), ecstasy (الوجد), yearning (الشوق), and similar types of knowledge. It is impossible for anyone to know these sciences except by being characterized by them and tasting them. An example of its likeness among the people of direct experience (أهل الذوق) is someone whose taste receptor is overcome by yellow bile, so he finds honey bitter, which is not the case [for honey itself], for what directly contacts the taste receptor is the yellow bile.

3. **Knowledge of Secrets (علوم الأسرار):** This is the knowledge that is above the sphere of the intellect (طور العقل). It is the knowledge breathed by the Holy Spirit (روح القدس) into the heart (الروع), specific to the Prophet and the Saint (الولي). It is of two types: a type that can be grasped by the intellect, like the first category of knowledge, but the one who knows it did not attain it through speculation; rather, the rank of this knowledge granted it. The other type is divided into two sub-types: one that is attached to the second knowledge (Knowledge of States), but its state is more noble; and the other sub-type is knowledge derived from reports (علوم الأخبار), which admits both truth and falsehood, unless the one reporting it has established truthfulness and infallibility (عصمته) in what he reports and says, such as the reports of the Prophets (peace and blessings of Allah be upon them) concerning Allah, like their reports about Paradise and what is in it.

His saying that there is a Paradise is from the knowledge of the Report (علم الخبر). His saying concerning the Resurrection that there is a Cistern (Ḥawḍ) sweeter than honey is from the knowledge of States (علم الأحوال), which is the knowledge of direct experience (علم الذوق). His saying: "Allah was, and there was nothing with Him," and similar statements, are from the knowledge of the Intellect (علوم العقل) grasped by speculation.

This third category, the Knowledge of Secrets (علم الأسرار), encompasses and absorbs all other knowledge. The possessor of the other types of knowledge is not like this. Therefore, there is no knowledge more noble than this encompassing knowledge (العلم المحيط) that contains all known things. The only remaining condition is that the one reporting it must be truthful and infallible (معصوما) in the eyes of those who hear him—this is the condition for the common people. As for the wise, intelligent person who advises himself, he does not reject it outright, but says: "It is permissible for me that this be true or false." This is how every rational person should treat these sciences when they come from someone who is not infallible (غير المعصوم), even if the reporter is truthful in reality (في نفس الأمر) concerning what he reports. Just as the listener is not obligated to affirm its truthfulness, he is not obligated to deny it, but should suspend judgment (يتوقف). If he affirms it, it does not harm him, because the report contains nothing that the intellect deems impossible, but rather something it permits or concerning which it suspends judgment. It does not demolish any pillar of the Sacred Law (الشريعة) or invalidate any of its fundamentals. If he brings forth a matter that the intellect permits and the Lawgiver (الشارع) is silent about, we should not reject it fundamentally, and we are given the choice to accept it. If the state of the reporter necessitates uprightness (العدالة), accepting it does not harm us, just as we accept his testimony and rule by it concerning wealth and lives. If he is not upright in our knowledge, we look: if what he reported is true by some valid aspect (وجه ما عندنا من الوجوه المصححة), we accept it; otherwise, we leave it in the category of the permissible (الجائزات) and do not speak ill of the one who said it. For it is a written testimony (شهادة مكتوبة) about which we will be questioned. Allah the Exalted said: <<سَتُكْتُبُ شَهادَتُهُمْ ويُسْئَلُونَ>> (Their testimony will be recorded, and they will be questioned). I am the most deserving of advising myself in this regard. If this reporter only brought what the infallible one brought, then he is merely relating to us what we already possess through transmission from him, so his report adds no benefit for us. Rather, they (may Allah be pleased with them) bring secrets and wisdom (أسرار وحكم) from the secrets of the Sacred Law that are beyond the power of thought and acquisition (الكسب) and are never attained except through witnessing (المشاهدة), inspiration (الإلهام), and similar paths. It is from this source that the benefit arises.

The Prophet’s saying: "If there are inspired people (محدثون) in my community, then ‘Umar is one of them." And his saying about Abu Bakr concerning his superiority through the secret (بالسر) over others. If the denial of this knowledge had not occurred in existence, the saying of Abu Hurayrah would have been meaningless: "I memorized two vessels of knowledge from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). As for one of them, I spread it. As for the other, if I were to spread it, this throat would be cut from me." This was narrated to me by the jurist Abu Abdullah Muhammad ibn Ubayd Allah al-Hajari in Ceuta in Ramadan of the year 589 AH, in his house. It was also narrated to me by Abu al-Walid Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn al-Arabi in his house in Seville in the year 592 AH, among others. All of them said, "He narrated to us," except Abu al-Walid ibn al-Arabi, who said, "I heard Abu al-Hasan Shurayh ibn Muhammad ibn Shurayh al-Ru’ayni say, 'My father, Abu Abdullah, and Abu Abdullah Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Manzur al-Qaysi narrated to me, having heard it from them, from Abu Dharr, having heard it from them, from Abu Muhammad—who is Abdullah ibn Ahmad ibn Hamawayh al-Sarakhsi al-Hamawi—and Abu Ishaq al-Mustamli, and Abu al-Haytham—who is Muhammad ibn Makki ibn Muhammad al-Kushmayhani—who said, "Abu Abdullah—who is Muhammad ibn Yusuf ibn Matar al-Firabri—narrated to us, saying, 'Abu Abdullah al-Bukhari narrated to us.'" It was also narrated to me by Abu Muhammad Yunus ibn Yahya ibn Abi al-Husayn ibn Abi al-Barakat al-Hashimi al-Abbasi in the Noble Sanctuary of Mecca, facing the Yemeni Corner of the Kaaba, in the month of Jumada al-Ula in the year 599 AH, from Abu al-Waqt Abd al-Awwal ibn Isa al-Sijzi al-Harawi, from Abu al-Hasan Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Muzaffar al-Dawudi, from Abu Muhammad Abdullah ibn Ahmad ibn Hamawayh al-Sarakhsi, from Abu Abdullah al-Firabri, from al-Bukhari. Al-Bukhari said in his *Ṣaḥīḥ*: "Ismail narrated to me, saying, 'My brother narrated to me, from Ibn Abi Dhi’b, from Sa’id al-Maqburi, from Abu Hurayrah,'" and he mentioned the hadith. The explanation of the throat (*al-bal‘ūm*) for Abu Abdullah al-Bukhari, from the narration of Abu Dharr, which he included in the Book of Knowledge, is that it is the passage for food.

The saying of Ibn Abbas would have been meaningless when he said concerning the verse: <<الله الَّذِي خَلَقَ سَبْعَ سَماواتٍ ومن الْأَرْضِ مِثْلَهُنَّ يَتَنَزَّلُ الْأَمْرُ بَيْنَهُنَّ>> (Allah is the one who created seven heavens and of the earth, the like of them. The command descends between them): "If I were to mention its interpretation, you would stone me," or in another narration, "you would say I am a disbeliever." This hadith was narrated to me by Abu Abdullah Muhammad ibn Ayshun, from Abu Bakr the Judge Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn al-Arabi al-Ma’afiri, from Abu Hamid Muhammad ibn Muhammad al-Tusi al-Ghazali.

The statement of al-Raḍī, one of the descendants of Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace and blessings be upon him), would have been meaningless when he said:

> O Lord, how many a jewel of knowledge, if I were to disclose it,
> It would be said to me: "You are one of those who worship idols."
> And Muslim men would deem my blood lawful,
> Seeing the ugliest of their actions as good.

All these individuals are righteous masters, as I reckon, and it is well-known about them that they recognized this knowledge, its rank, and the position of most of the world concerning it—that the majority deny it. The rational Gnostic (العاقل العارف) should not hold their denial against them, for the story of Moses with Khidr provides them with an excuse and serves as a proof for both parties, even though Moses’ denial stemmed from forgetting his condition and Allah’s rectification of him. We use this very story as an argument against the deniers, but there is no way to dispute with them. Rather, we say, as the righteous servant (Khidr) said: <<هذا فِراقُ بَيْنِي وبَيْنِكَ>> (This is the separation between me and you).

### [On Prophetic Knowledge and Speculative Knowledge (في العلم النبوي والعلم النظري)]

O observer of this type of knowledge, which is the Prophetic Knowledge (العلم النبوي) inherited from them (peace and blessings be upon them), do not let it veil you if you encounter one of their issues mentioned by a philosopher, a theologian (متكلم), or a person of speculation (صاحب نظر) in any science. Do not say of this speaker, who is the verifying Sufi (الصوفي المحقق), that he is a philosopher because the philosopher mentioned that issue, affirmed it, and believed in it, or that the Sufi copied it from them, or that the Sufi has no religion, because the philosopher affirmed it and has no religion. Do not do this, my brother, for this statement is the statement of one who lacks comprehension (لا تحصيل له). Not all of the philosopher’s knowledge is false. Perhaps that specific issue is among the truths he possesses, especially if we find that the Messenger (peace be upon him) also affirmed it, particularly concerning the wisdom they established, the renunciation of desires (الشهوات), the snares of the lower soul (مكايد النفوس), and the evil intentions it harbors. If we do not know the realities (الحقائق), we should affirm that the philosopher’s statement on this specific issue is true, since the Messenger (peace be upon him), or a Companion, or Malik, or Shafi’i, or Sufyan al-Thawri affirmed it. As for your saying that the Sufi heard it from a philosopher or read it in their books, you may fall into lying and ignorance. Lying, because you say he heard or read it when you did not witness that from him. Ignorance, because you fail to distinguish between truth and falsehood in that issue. As for your saying that the philosopher has no religion, his lack of religion does not imply that everything he possesses is false. This is grasped by the first principle of reason (أول العقل) for every rational person. By objecting to the Sufi on such an issue, you have departed from knowledge, truthfulness, and religion, and have joined the ranks of the ignorant, the liars, the slanderers, those deficient in intellect and religion, and those with corrupt and deviated speculation.

Consider if this knowledge came to you through a vision (رؤيا) he saw—would you not interpret it and seek its meanings? Likewise, take what this Sufi brings you, guide yourself slightly, and empty your vessel for what he brings, so that its meaning may become clear to you. This is better than saying on the Day of Resurrection: <<قَدْ كُنَّا في غَفْلَةٍ من هذا بَلْ كُنَّا ظالِمِينَ>> (We were certainly in unawareness of this; rather, we were wrongdoers).

Any knowledge whose expression is clear, whose meaning is understood or nearly understood, and which is sweet to the understanding listener, is the knowledge of the speculative intellect (علم العقل النظري), because it falls within its grasp and is something it can independently achieve through speculation. However, the Knowledge of Secrets (علم الأسرار), when expressed, becomes ugly (سمج), its comprehension becomes difficult (اعتاص), and it becomes harsh. Weak, prejudiced intellects that have not fully utilized the deployment of their reality (تصريف حقيقتها) which Allah placed within them for speculation and research may even reject it. This is why the possessor of this knowledge often conveys it to understandings by giving examples and poetic addresses.

The Knowledge of States (علوم الأحوال) is intermediate between the Knowledge of Secrets and the Knowledge of Intellects. Most people who believe in the Knowledge of States are those who have experienced it (أهل التجارب). It is closer to the Knowledge of Secrets than to the speculative intellectual knowledge (العلم النظري العقلي). However, it approaches the category of necessary intellectual knowledge (العلم العقلي الضروري); indeed, it *is* that, but because intellects cannot reach it except through reports from a Prophet or Saint who knows or witnesses it, it is distinguished from necessary knowledge. Yet, it is necessary for the one who witnesses it. Know that if it seems good to you, and you accept it and believe in it, then rejoice, for you are necessarily on the verge of an Unveiling (كشف) of it, even if you do not realize it. There is no other way, for the heart is only satisfied by what is decisively proven to be correct. The intellect has no entry here, because it is not within its grasp, unless an infallible person brings it; then the heart of the rational person is satisfied. But the non-infallible person’s words are only enjoyed by the person of direct experience (صاحب ذوق).

### [The Method of the People of the Real (أهل الحق) in their Journey to the Real (الحق)]

(If you say): Summarize for me this path (الطريقة) which you claim is the noble path that leads the traveler (السالك) upon it to Allah the Exalted, and what it encompasses of realities (الحقائق) and stations (المقامات), using the briefest, most concise, and most eloquent expression, so that I may act upon it and reach what you claimed to have reached. I swear by Allah that I do not take it from you by way of experimentation or testing, but I take it from you in sincerity, for I have formed a decisive good opinion of you, since you have alerted me to the portion of intellect I possess, and that what you brought is something the intellect affirms as permissible and possible, or concerning which it suspends judgment without a definite ruling. May Allah thank you for that, grant you your hopes, and benefit you and benefit others through you.

Know that the path to Allah the Exalted, which the elite (الخاصة) of the believers seeking their salvation—not the common people (العامة) who occupy themselves with what they were not created for—have traveled, rests upon four branches: Impulses (بواعث), Motivations (دواع), Virtues (أخلاق), and Realities (حقائق).

What motivates them to these Motivations, Impulses, Virtues, and Realities are three duties (حقوق) incumbent upon them: a duty to Allah, a duty to themselves, and a duty to Creation (الخلق).

The duty to Allah the Exalted upon them is that they worship Him and associate nothing with Him.

The duty to Creation upon them is to restrain all harm from them, unless commanded by the Sacred Law (like establishing a legal penalty), and to perform acts of kindness (صنائع المعروف) toward them to the best of their ability and with preference (الإيثار), provided the Sacred Law does not forbid it, for there is no way to conform to the Divine Purpose except through the tongue of the Sacred Law.

The duty to themselves upon them is that they only lead the soul (النفس) along paths that contain its happiness and salvation, even if it resists. If it resists, it is due to ignorance residing within it or a bad disposition. The resisting soul is only compelled to perform virtuous deeds (الأخلاق الفاضلة) by religion or chivalry (مروءة). Ignorance contradicts religion, for religion is a science among the sciences, and a bad disposition contradicts chivalry.

Then we return to the four branches and say:

The **Motivations (الدواعي)** are five: The causal thought (الهاجس السببي), also called the sudden thought (نفر الخاطر); then Intention (الإرادة); then Resolve (العزم); then Aspiration (الهمة); then Purpose (النية).

The **Impulses (البواعث)** for these Motivations are three things: Desire (رغبة), Fear (رهبة), or Magnification (تعظيم). Desire is of two types: Desire for proximity (المجاورة) and Desire for witnessing (المعاينة). Or, if you wish, Desire for what is with Him and Desire for Him. Fear is of two types: Fear of punishment (العذاب) and Fear of veiling (الحجاب). Magnification is isolating Him from yourself and gathering yourself with Him.

The **Virtues (الأخلاق)** are of three types: Transitive virtue (خلق متعد), Intransitive virtue (خلق غير متعد), and Shared virtue (خلق مشترك). The Transitive is of two sub-types: Transitive by benefit, like generosity (الجود) and spiritual chivalry (الفتوة); and Transitive by repelling harm, like pardon (العفو), forbearance (الصفح), and enduring harm while having the power to retaliate and the ability to do so. The Intransitive is like scrupulousness (الورع), asceticism (الزهد), and reliance (التوكل). The Shared is like patience (الصبر) regarding harm from Creation and showing a cheerful face (بسط الوجه).

The **Realities (الحقائق)** are of four types: Realities pertaining to the Sacred Essence (الذات المقدسة); Realities pertaining to the Transcendent Attributes (الصفات المنزهة), which are the Relations (النسب); Realities pertaining to the Acts (الأفعال), which are *Kun* (Be) and its sisters; and Realities pertaining to the Effects (المفعولات), which are the Existents (الأكوان) and the Formed Things (المكونات). These cosmic realities are of three ranks: Celestial (علوية), which are the Intelligibles (المعقولات); Terrestrial (سفلية), which are the Sensibles (المحسوسات); and Intermediary (برزخية), which are the Imaginations (المخيلات).

As for the **Essential Realities (الحقائق الذاتية)**, they are every station (مشهد) in which the Real (الحق) establishes you without anthropomorphism (تشبيه) or modality (تكييف), which expression cannot encompass and to which indication cannot point.

As for the **Attributive Realities (الحقائق الصفاتية)**, they are every station in which the Real establishes you, from which you gain knowledge of His being All-Knowing, All-Powerful, Willing, Living, and so forth, of the differing, opposing, and similar Names and Attributes.

As for the **Cosmic Realities (الحقائق الكونية)**, they are every station in which the Real establishes you, from which you gain knowledge of the spirits (الأرواح), the simple substances (البسائط), the composite substances (المركبات), the bodies (الأجسام), connection (الاتصال), and separation (الانفصال).

As for the **Active Realities (الحقائق الفعلية)**, they are every station in which the Real establishes you, from which you gain knowledge of *Kun* and the specific connection of Power (القدرة) to the object of power (المقدور), because the servant has no act (فعل) and his contingent power (قدرته الحادثة) has no effect.

All that we have mentioned is called States (الأحوال) and Stations (المقامات). The **Station (المقام)** is every quality in which permanence (الرسوخ) is necessary and from which transition is not valid, such as repentance (التوبة). The **State (الحال)** is every quality that exists at one time but not another, such as intoxication (السكر), effacement (المحو), absence (الغيبة), and contentment (الرضي), or whose existence is conditional upon a condition, so it ceases when its condition ceases, such as patience with affliction and gratitude with blessing.

These matters are of two types. One type is whose perfection is in the outward and inward of the human, like scrupulousness and repentance. The second type is whose perfection is in the inward of the human, and if the outward follows, there is no harm, like asceticism and reliance. There is no station on the path to Allah the Exalted that exists in the outward without the inward.

Furthermore, some of these stations characterize the human in this world and the Hereafter, such as witnessing (المشاهدة), Majesty (الجلال), Beauty (الجمال), intimacy (الأنس), awe (الهيبة), and expansion (البسط). Some qualities characterize the servant until his death, until the Resurrection, until the first step he places in Paradise, and then they vanish, such as fear (الخوف), contraction (القبض), sorrow (الحزن), and hope (الرجاء). Some qualities characterize the servant until his death, such as asceticism, repentance, scrupulousness, striving (المجاهدة), spiritual discipline (الرياضة), emptying (التخلي), and adorning (التحلي) on the path of proximity (القربة). Some qualities vanish when their condition vanishes and return when their condition returns, such as patience, gratitude, and scrupulousness.

This, which Allah has granted us and you, is the path I have clarified for you, with its stations ordered and its meanings and realities made manifest, with the utmost conciseness, clarity, and comprehensive fulfillment. If you travel it, you will arrive. And Allah the Exalted guides us and you.

### [The Seven Issues Specific to the Knowledge of the People of the Real]

The core of the knowledge specific to the People of Allah (أهل الله) the Exalted revolves around seven issues. Whoever knows them will find nothing difficult in the science of Realities (علم الحقائق). They are:

1. Knowledge of the Names of Allah (أسماء الله تعالى).
2. Knowledge of the Theophanies (التجليات).
3. Knowledge of the address of the Real (خطاب الحق) to His servants through the tongue of the Sacred Law.
4. Knowledge of the perfection and deficiency of Being (الوجود).
5. Knowledge of the Human (الإنسان) from the perspective of his realities.
6. Knowledge of Imaginative Unveiling (الكشف الخيالي).
7. Knowledge of the causes (العلل) and the remedies (الأدوية).

We mentioned these issues in the Chapter on Gnosis (باب المعرفة) in this book, so let them be examined there, if Allah wills.

### [Supplement: On Speculation Concerning the Soundness of Doctrines from the Perspective of Scholastic Theology (علم الكلام)]

Then we return to the reason why we prevented the prepared seeker for the Theophany (تجلى) of the Real into his heart from engaging in speculation concerning the soundness of doctrines from the perspective of Scholastic Theology (علم الكلام).

One reason is that the doctrines of the common people (العوام)—without dispute among any sound-minded person adhering to the Sacred Law—are sound, and they are Muslims, even though they have not studied anything of Scholastic Theology nor known the doctrines of the opponents. Rather, Allah the Exalted preserved them upon the soundness of the primordial nature (صحة الفطرة), which is the knowledge of the existence of Allah the Exalted, through the instruction of a parent or educator adhering to the Sacred Law. They are, by the grace of Allah, upon soundness and correctness in their knowledge of the Real (الحق) and His transcendence (تنزيهه) according to the rule of knowledge and transcendence found in the manifest Qur’an, so long as none of them resorts to allegorical interpretation (التأويل). If one of them resorts to allegorical interpretation, he leaves the category of the common people and becomes verified in a category of the people of speculation and interpretation, and his fate depends on his interpretation. He will meet Allah accordingly, either being correct or mistaken, depending on what contradicts the manifest meaning brought by the Sacred Law.

The common people, by the grace of Allah, have sound doctrines because they received them from the manifest meaning of the Noble Book (الكتاب العزيز), a reception that necessitates certainty (القطع). This is because continuous transmission (التواتر) is one of the paths leading to Knowledge (العلم). The purpose of Knowledge is nothing but certainty regarding the known thing, that it is exactly as we know it, without doubt or suspicion. The Noble Qur’an is established for us by continuous transmission that a person claimed to be a Messenger from Allah the Exalted and brought what proves his truthfulness, which is this Qur’an, and that no one was ever able to challenge it. Thus, it is established for us by continuous transmission that he is the Messenger of Allah to us, and that he brought this Qur’an which is before us today, and he reported that it is the Speech of Allah. All this is established for us by continuous transmission, so the Knowledge is established that it is the True News (النبأ الحق) and the Decisive Word (القول الفصل).

Proofs are transmitted (سمعية) and rational (عقلية). If we rule upon a matter with a certain ruling, there is no doubt that it is according to that ruling. Since the matter is as we have stated, the prepared seeker should take his doctrine from the Noble Qur’an, which is equivalent to the rational proof (الدليل العقلي) in its indication, for it is the Truth (الصدق) <<لا يَأْتِيهِ الْباطِلُ من بَيْنِ يَدَيْهِ ولا من خَلْفِهِ تَنْزِيلٌ من حَكِيمٍ حَمِيدٍ>> (Falsehood cannot approach it from before it or from behind it; [it is] a revelation from a Wise, Praiseworthy [Lord]).

The prepared seeker does not need rational proofs (أدلة العقول) once this fundamental principle is established, for he has attained the decisive proof (الدليل القاطع) upon which the sword is suspended, and consensus (الإصفاق) upon it is verified for him. The Jews said to Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him): "Attribute your Lord to us." So Allah revealed Sūrat al-Ikhlāṣ (Q 112), and He did not establish for them a single proof from rational speculation. He said: <<قُلْ هُوَ الله>> (Say: He is Allah)—thus affirming Being (الوجود). <<أَحَدٌ>> (The One)—thus negating number and affirming the Oneness (الأحدية) of Allah the Exalted. <<الله الصَّمَدُ>> (Allah, the Eternal Refuge)—thus negating corporeality (الجسم). <<لَمْ يَلِدْ ولَمْ يُولَدْ>> (He neither begets nor is born)—thus negating parent and child. <<ولَمْ يَكُنْ لَهُ كُفُواً أَحَدٌ>> (Nor is there to Him any equivalent)—thus negating a consort, just as He negated a partner by His saying: <<لَوْ كانَ فِيهِما آلِهَةٌ إِلَّا الله لَفَسَدَتا>> (If there were in them [the heavens and earth] gods besides Allah, they would have been ruined).

The person seeking rational proof demands demonstration of the soundness of these meanings through the intellect, yet the wording itself has already indicated its soundness! I wish I knew the state of this person who seeks to know Allah through proof and declares the non-speculator a disbeliever: What was his state before speculation and during speculation? Was he a Muslim or not? Did he pray and fast, or was it established for him that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah to him, or that Allah exists? If he believed all this, then this is the state of the common people, so let him leave them upon what they are and not declare anyone a disbeliever. If he did not believe this until he speculated and read Scholastic Theology, then we seek refuge in Allah from this doctrine, where poor speculation led him to abandon faith.

The scholars of this science (may Allah be pleased with them) did not establish it or write their works in it to establish knowledge of Allah within themselves. Rather, they established it to repel opponents who denied the Godhead, or the Attributes, or some Attributes, or the Messengership, or the Messengership of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) specifically, or the contingency of the world, or the return to these bodies after death, or the Gathering and Resurrection, and related matters. These opponents were disbelievers in the Qur’an, denying and rejecting it. The scholars of Scholastic Theology sought to establish proofs against them using the method they claimed led them to invalidate what we claimed was true, specifically so that they would not confuse the doctrines of the common people. Whenever a claimant appeared in the arena of debate, an Ash’ari or one of the people of speculation would appear to him. They did not rely solely on the sword, but were eager and keen to bring someone back to faith and join the community of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) through demonstration (البرهان). Since the person who brought the miraculous sign proving his claim (the Messenger) is absent, the demonstration, in their view, stands in place of that miracle for the one who understands. The one who returns through demonstration is sounder in his Islam than the one who returns through the sword, for fear can lead to hypocrisy, but the person of demonstration is not so. For this reason (may Allah be pleased with them), they established the science of substance (الجوهر) and accident (العرض), and nothing else. One person in a city is sufficient for it.

If a person believes in the Qur’an as the Speech of Allah and is certain of it, let him take his doctrine from it without allegorical interpretation (تأويل) or deviation. He transcended Himself from being resembled by anything created or resembling anything by His saying: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ وهُوَ السَّمِيعُ الْبَصِيرُ>> (There is nothing like unto Him, and He is the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing). And: <<وسُبْحانَ رَبِّكَ رَبِّ الْعِزَّةِ عَمَّا يَصِفُونَ>> (Exalted is your Lord, the Lord of Might, above what they describe).

He affirmed His vision in the Hereafter by the manifest meaning of His saying: <<وُجُوهٌ يَوْمَئِذٍ ناضِرَةٌ إِلى‏ رَبِّها ناظِرَةٌ>> (Some faces, that Day, will be radiant, looking at their Lord). And: <<وكَلَّا إِنَّهُمْ عَنْ رَبِّهِمْ يَوْمَئِذٍ لَمَحْجُوبُونَ>> (No! Indeed, from their Lord, that Day, they will be veiled). The encompassing of His perception is negated by His saying: <<لا تُدْرِكُهُ الْأَبْصارُ>> (Vision cannot perceive Him). His being All-Powerful is affirmed by His saying: <<وهُوَ عَلى‏ كُلِّ شَيْ‏ءٍ قَدِيرٌ>> (And He is over all things competent). His being All-Knowing is affirmed by His saying: <<أَحاطَ بِكُلِّ شَيْ‏ءٍ عِلْماً>> (He has encompassed all things in knowledge). His being Willing is affirmed by His saying: <<فَعَّالٌ لِما يُرِيدُ>> (A doer of what He intends). His being All-Hearing is affirmed by His saying: <<لَقَدْ سَمِعَ الله>> (Allah has certainly heard). His being All-Seeing is affirmed by His saying: <<أَ لَمْ يَعْلَمْ بِأَنَّ الله يَرى‏>> (Does he not know that Allah sees?). His being a Speaker is affirmed by His saying: <<وكَلَّمَ الله مُوسى‏ تَكْلِيماً>> (And Allah spoke to Moses directly). His being Living is affirmed by His saying: <<الله لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْحَيُّ الْقَيُّومُ>> (Allah—there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of [all] existence). The sending of Messengers is affirmed by His saying: <<وما أَرْسَلْنا من قَبْلِكَ إِلَّا رِجالًا نُوحِي إِلَيْهِمْ>> (And We sent not before you except men to whom We revealed). The Messengership of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) is affirmed by His saying: <<مُحَمَّدٌ رَسُولُ الله>> (Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah). His being the last of the Prophets is affirmed by His saying: <<وخاتَمَ النَّبِيِّينَ>> (And the Seal of the Prophets). That everything besides Him is His creation is affirmed by His saying: <<الله خالِقُ كُلِّ شَيْ‏ءٍ>> (Allah is the Creator of all things). The creation of the jinn is affirmed by His saying: <<وما خَلَقْتُ الْجِنَّ والْإِنْسَ إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُونِ>> (And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me). The resurrection of bodies is affirmed by His saying: <<مِنْها خَلَقْناكُمْ وفِيها نُعِيدُكُمْ ومِنْها نُخْرِجُكُمْ تارَةً أُخْرى‏>> (From the earth We created you, and into it We will return you, and from it We will bring you forth again). And similar verses concerning what doctrines require: the Gathering, the Resurrection, Divine Decree (القضاء والقدر), Paradise, Hell, the Grave, the Scale (الميزان), the Cistern (الحوض), the Bridge (الصراط), the Reckoning (الحساب), and the Scrolls (الصحف)—everything the believer must believe. He said: <<ما فَرَّطْنا في الْكِتابِ من شَيْ‏ءٍ>> (We have not neglected in the Register a thing).

And this Qur’an is his miracle (peace be upon him), proven by the challenge to oppose it and the inability to do so, in His saying: <<قُلْ فَأْتُوا بِسُورَةٍ مِثْلِهِ>> (Say, "Then produce a surah like it"). Then He decisively stated that opposition would never occur by His saying: <<قُلْ لَئِنِ اجْتَمَعَتِ الْإِنْسُ والْجِنُّ عَلى‏ أَنْ يَأْتُوا بِمِثْلِ هذَا الْقُرْآنِ لا يَأْتُونَ بِمِثْلِهِ ولَوْ كانَ بَعْضُهُمْ لِبَعْضٍ ظَهِيراً>> (Say, "If mankind and the jinn gathered in order to produce the like of this Qur’an, they could not produce the like of it, even if they were to each other assistants"). And He reported the inability of those who wished to oppose it and their admission that the matter was immense, saying: <<إِنَّهُ فَكَّرَ وقَدَّرَ>> (Indeed, he thought and deliberated) up to His saying: <<إِنْ هذا إِلَّا سِحْرٌ يُؤْثَرُ>> (This is not but magic derived [from others]).

In the Noble Qur’an, there is great sufficiency for the rational person, and a cure and healing for the chronic disease, as He said: <<ونُنَزِّلُ من الْقُرْآنِ ما هُوَ شِفاءٌ ورَحْمَةٌ لِلْمُؤْمِنِينَ>> (And We send down of the Qur’an that which is a healing and a mercy for the believers). It is a sufficient and satisfying conviction for whoever resolves upon the path of salvation and desires high ranks, abandoning the sciences that introduce doubts and suspicions, thereby wasting time and risking Divine displeasure (المقت), for the adherent of that method rarely escapes distraction (التشغيب) or engages in the discipline and refinement of his soul, since his time is consumed in repelling opponents who do not exist in reality and warding off doubts that might occur to the opponent.

And if it has not occurred, it may occur, or it may not occur. But if it does occur, the sword of the Law (الشريعة) is more deterrent and decisive. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "I have been commanded to fight the people until they say, 'There is no god but Allah,' and until they believe in me and in what I have brought." This is his saying (peace and blessings be upon him), and he did not urge us to debate them when they appeared; rather, it was through struggle (*al-Jihad*) and the sword if they resisted what was conveyed to them. So how can we deal with an imaginary opponent, wasting time debating him, when we have neither seen him nor heard him say anything? We are only dealing with what arises within our own souls, imagining that we are engaging with someone else. Nevertheless, may Allah be pleased with them, they exerted effort and intended good, even if what they neglected was more obligatory upon them than that with which they occupied themselves. May Allah benefit everyone through their intention. Were it not for the lengthiness, I would speak about the stations (*maqamat*) and levels (*maratib*) of the sciences. Although speculative theology (*‘ilm al-Kalam*) is honorable, most people do not need it; rather, one person suffices for a town, like a physician. Jurists (*al-Fuqaha’*) who are scholars of the branches of religion are not like that; people need a large number of scholars of the Law (الشريعة). And in the Law, praise be to Allah, there is richness and sufficiency. If a person were to die without knowing the terminology of those who engage in speculative reasoning (*‘ilm al-Nazar*), such as substance (*al-jawhar*), accident (*al-’arad*), body (*al-jism*), corporeal (*al-jismani*), spirit (*al-ruh*), and spiritual (*al-ruhani*), Allah the Exalted would not question him about that. Allah only questions people specifically about the obligations (*al-taklif*) He imposed upon them. May Allah grant us modesty before Him.

(Section) Concerning what should be generally believed.

This is the creed (*‘aqida*) of the People of Islam, accepted without recourse to proof (*dalil*) or demonstration (*burhan*). O my believing brethren, may Allah grant us and you a good ending. When I heard the saying of Allah the Exalted concerning His Prophet Hud (peace be upon him), when he said to his people who denied him and his message: <<إِنِّي أُشْهِدُ الله واشْهَدُوا أَنِّي بَرِي‏ءٌ مِمَّا تُشْرِكُونَ>> (Indeed, I call Allah to witness, and you yourselves witness, that I am innocent of what you associate [with Him]), the Prophet (peace be upon him) called his people, despite their denial of him, to witness his own declaration of innocence from associating partners with Allah (*shirk*) and his affirmation of His Oneness (*ahadiyya*). This is because he (peace be upon him) knew that Allah the Glorious will make His servants stand before Him and question them about what He already knows, in order to establish the proof for or against them, so that every witness may render his testimony. It has been reported that the caller to prayer (*al-mu’adhdhin*) is witnessed for by everything wet and dry within the range of his voice, and everyone who hears him. This is why Satan turns away when the call to prayer (*adhan*) is made, fleeing with a sound (in one narration, with flatulence). This is so that he does not hear the caller’s proclamation of the testimony, which would oblige him to bear witness for the caller. By bearing that testimony, he would become one of those who strive for the happiness of the one testified for, even though he is a pure enemy who holds absolutely no good for us—may Allah curse him. If the enemy is compelled to testify for you concerning what you have called him to witness regarding yourself, then it is even more fitting that your friend, your beloved, and those who share your religion and community should testify for you. And it is even more fitting that you should call them to witness your own affirmation of Unity (*al-wahdaniyya*) and faith (*al-iman*) in this worldly abode.

### [The First Testimony]

O my brethren and my beloved, may Allah be pleased with you. I call you to witness—I, a weak, destitute servant, poor unto Allah the Exalted in every moment and blink of an eye, the author and originator of this book—I call you to witness concerning myself, after having called Allah the Exalted, His angels, and every believer present or hearing this, that I testify, both verbally and by conviction (*‘aqdan*), that Allah the Exalted is one God (*Ilah wahid*), having no second in His Divinity (*uluhiyya*). He is transcendent (*munazzah*) above having a consort or a child. He is a Sovereign (*Malik*) with no partner, a King with no minister, a Creator (*Sani’*) with no co-manager. He exists by His Essence (*mawjud bi-dhatihi*) without needing an originator to bring Him into existence. Rather, every existence other than Him is dependent upon Him the Exalted for its existence. Thus, the entire cosmos (*al-’alam*) exists through Him, and He alone is characterized by Existence (*al-Wujud*) for Himself. There is no beginning to His Existence and no end to His Subsistence (*baqa’*); rather, He is Absolute Existence (*wujud mutlaq*), unconditioned, subsisting by Himself (*qa’im bi-nafsihi*). He is not a substance (*jawhar*) occupying space, such that location could be assigned to Him, nor is He an accident (*‘arad*), such that subsistence would be impossible for Him, nor is He a body (*jism*), such that direction (*jiha*) and orientation could be ascribed to Him. He is sanctified (*muqaddas*) above directions and regions (*al-aqtar*). He is seen by hearts and eyes when He wills. He established Himself upon His Throne (*‘arsh*) as He stated, and in the manner He intended, just as the Throne and everything besides it is established by Him. To Him belong the Last and the First. He has no conceivable likeness, nor can intellects point to Him. He is not limited by time (*zaman*) nor contained by space (*makan*). Rather, He was, and there was no place, and He is now as He was. He created the localized and the location, and originated time. He said, "I am the One, the Living." The preservation of creation does not weary Him. No attribute that was not already His returns to Him through the making of created things. Exalted is He above being indwelt by contingent events (*al-hawadith*) or indwelling them, or their existing after Him, or His existing before them. Rather, it is said: He was, and nothing was with Him, for "before" and "after" are forms of the time He originated. He is the Self-Subsisting (*al-Qayyum*) who does not sleep, the Dominant (*al-Qahhar*) who cannot be resisted. <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). He created the Throne and made it the limit of His establishment (*hadd al-istiwa’*). He originated the Footstool (*al-Kursi*) and encompassed the earth and the high heavens. He invented the Tablet (*al-Lawh*) and the Supreme Pen (*al-Qalam al-A’la*) and set it running, writing with His Knowledge concerning His creation until the Day of Separation and Judgment. He originated the entire cosmos (*al-’alam*) without a prior example, and He created creation and made what He created old. He sent down the spirits (*al-arwah*) into the bodies (*al-ashbah*) as trustees, and made these bodies, into which the spirits were sent down, vicegerents (*khulafa’*) on earth. He subjected to us <<ما في السَّماواتِ وما في الْأَرْضِ جَمِيعاً مِنْهُ>> (whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth—all from Him). Not a single atom moves except towards Him and from Him. He created everything without need for it, and without any necessity obligating Him to do so. Rather, His Knowledge preceded that He would create what He created. Thus, <<هُوَ الْأَوَّلُ والْآخِرُ والظَّاهِرُ والْباطِنُ وهُوَ عَلى‏ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ قَدِيرٌ>> (He is the First and the Last, the Manifest and the Hidden, and He is over all things competent). <<أَحاطَ بِكُلِّ شَيْءٍ عِلْماً وأَحْصى‏ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ عَدَداً>> (He encompasses everything in Knowledge and enumerates everything in number). <<يَعْلَمُ السِّرَّ وأَخْفى‏>> (He knows the secret and what is more hidden). <<يَعْلَمُ خائِنَةَ الْأَعْيُنِ وما تُخْفِي الصُّدُورُ>> (He knows the deceit of the eyes and what the breasts conceal). How could He not know something that is His creation? <<أَ لا يَعْلَمُ من خَلَقَ وهُوَ اللَّطِيفُ الْخَبِيرُ>> (Does He who created not know? And He is the Subtle, the Acquainted). He knew things in their essences (*a’yan*) before their existence, then brought them into existence exactly as He knew them. He has always been Knower of things; no new knowledge accrues to Him when creation is renewed. By His Knowledge, He perfected and established things, and by it, He judged and governed whom He willed. He knows universals absolutely, just as He knows particulars, by the consensus and agreement of the people of sound speculation (*al-nazar al-sahih*). Thus, He is <<عالِمِ الْغَيْبِ والشَّهادَةِ فَتَعالى‏ عَمَّا يُشْرِكُونَ>> (Knower of the unseen and the witnessed, so exalted is He above what they associate [with Him]). He is <<فَعَّالٌ لِما يُرِيدُ>> (Doer of what He wills). He is the Willer of all contingent events (*al-ka’inat*) in the realm of earth and heavens. His Power (*qudra*) did not relate to anything until He willed it, just as He did not will it until He knew it. For it is rationally impossible for the mind to will what it does not know, or for the chosen agent, who is capable of abandoning that action, to perform what he does not will. Likewise, it is impossible for the relations (*nisab*) of these realities (*haqa’iq*) to exist in anything other than a living being, just as it is impossible for Attributes (*sifat*) to subsist without an Essence (*Dhat*) described by them. Therefore, nothing in Existence (*al-Wujud*)—neither obedience nor disobedience, neither profit nor loss, neither slave nor free, neither cold nor heat, neither life nor death, neither attainment nor failure, neither day nor night, neither moderation nor deviation, neither land nor sea, neither even nor odd, neither substance (*jawhar*) nor accident (*‘arad*), neither health nor sickness, neither joy nor sorrow, neither spirit (*ruh*) nor phantom (*shabah*), neither darkness nor light, neither earth nor sky, neither composition nor analysis, neither much nor little, neither morning nor evening, neither white nor black, neither sleep nor wakefulness, neither manifest (*zahir*) nor hidden (*batin*), neither moving nor still, neither dry nor wet, neither husk nor kernel, nor anything of these contradictory, differing, or similar relations—exists except that it is willed by the Real (*al-Haqq*) the Exalted. How could it not be willed by Him when He brought it into existence? How could the Chosen Agent bring into existence what He does not will? There is no repeller of His command and no annuller of His judgment. He gives sovereignty to whom He wills and takes sovereignty from whom He wills. He honors whom He wills and humiliates whom He wills. <<يُضِلُّ من يَشاءُ ويَهْدِي من يَشاءُ>> (He leads astray whom He wills and guides whom He wills). What He willed was, and what He did not will to be, was not. If all creatures were to gather to will something that Allah the Exalted did not will them to will, they would not will it. Or if they were to perform something that Allah the Exalted did not will to bring into existence, even if they willed it when He willed them to will it, they would not perform it, nor would they be able to, nor would He empower them for it. Thus, disbelief (*kufr*) and faith (*iman*), obedience and disobedience, are all from His Will (*mashi’a*), His Judgment (*hukm*), and His Intention (*irada*). He the Glorious has always been described by this Will eternally (*azalan*), while the cosmos was non-existent and uncreated, even though it was fixed (*thabit*) in Knowledge in its immutable essence (*‘ayn*). Then He brought the cosmos into existence without reflection or deliberation arising from ignorance or lack of knowledge, such that reflection and deliberation would grant Him knowledge of what He was ignorant of. Exalted and Glorified is He above that! Rather, He brought it into existence based on prior Knowledge and the determination of the transcendent, eternal Will (*al-Irada al-Azaliyya*), which decreed upon the cosmos what it brought it into existence upon, in terms of time, place, states, and colors. Therefore, there is truly no Willer in Existence (*al-Wujud*) other than Him, for He the Glorious is the One who says: <<وما تَشاؤُنَ إِلَّا أَنْ يَشاءَ الله>> (And you do not will except that Allah wills). And just as He the Glorious knew, so He judged; and willed, so He specified; and decreed, so He brought into existence; likewise, He heard and saw whatever moved, rested, or spoke among mankind, in the lower and upper worlds (*al-’alam*). Distance does not veil His hearing, for He is the Near. Proximity does not veil His sight, for He is the Far. He hears the speech of the soul within the soul, and the sound of subtle contact upon touching. He sees blackness in the deepest darkness and water within water. Neither blending, nor darkness, nor light veils Him. He is the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing (*al-Sami’ al-Basir*). He the Glorious spoke, not out of prior silence or imagined muteness, but with an eternal, primordial Speech (*Kalam qadim azali*), like the rest of His Attributes—His Knowledge, His Will, and His Power. With it, He spoke to Moses (peace be upon him). He named it the Revelation (*al-Tanzil*), the Psalms (*al-Zabur*), the Torah (*al-Tawrat*), and the Gospel (*al-Injil*), without letters, sounds, melodies, or languages. Rather, He is the Creator of sounds, letters, and languages. Thus, His Speech (Glorified is He) is without palate or tongue, just as His hearing is without inner ear or outer ears, and His sight is without pupil or eyelids, and His Will is without heart or inner being, and His Knowledge is without compulsion or recourse to demonstration (*burhan*), and His Life is without the vapor of a heart cavity resulting from the mixing of elements, just as His Essence (*Dhat*) accepts neither increase nor decrease. So Glory be to Him, Glory be to Him, the Distant yet Near, Mighty in Sovereignty, Abundant in Goodness, Immense in Favor. Everything other than Him flows from His Generosity, and His Grace and Justice are the ones who expand and contract it. He perfected the making of the cosmos and originated it when He brought it into existence and invented it. He has no partner in His dominion, nor any co-manager in His kingdom. If He bestows favor, that is His grace; and if He afflicts and punishes, that is His justice. He does not act in the dominion of another such that He could be accused of tyranny or injustice, nor is any judgment imposed upon Him by another such that He would be characterized by anxiety or fear because of it. Everything besides Him is under the authority of His Dominance (*qahr*) and acts according to His Will and Command. He is the Inspirer of piety (*taqwa*) and wickedness (*fujur*) into the souls of those held accountable (*al-mukallafin*). He is the Forgiver of the sins of whom He wills, and the Punisher of whom He wills, both here and on the Day of Resurrection (*al-Nushur*). His Justice does not govern His Grace, nor does His Grace govern His Justice. He brought forth the cosmos in two handfuls and established two abodes for them, saying: "These are for Paradise, and I care not; and these are for the Fire, and I care not." No objector objected to Him there, for there was no existent being besides Him. Thus, all are under the disposition of His Names (*Asma’*): one handful under the Names of His affliction (*bala’*) and one handful under the Names of His blessings (*ala’*). If He the Glorious had willed that the entire cosmos be happy, it would have been so; or wretched, it would have been so. But He the Glorious did not will that, so it was as He willed. Thus, among them are the wretched and the happy, both here and on the Day of Return (*al-Ma’ad*). There is no way to alter what the Eternal (*al-Qadim*) has decreed. Allah the Exalted said concerning the prayer: "They are five, and they are fifty." <<ما يُبَدَّلُ الْقَوْلُ لَدَيَّ وما أَنَا بِظَلَّامٍ لِلْعَبِيدِ>> (The word will not be changed with Me, and I am not a tyrant to the servants), due to My disposal in My dominion and the execution of My Will in My kingdom. This is due to a Reality (*haqiqa*) that eyes and insights (*basa’ir*) are blind to, and which thoughts and consciences cannot discover, except through a Divine gift (*wahb ilahi*) and a Merciful bestowal (*jud rahmani*) granted to the servant whom Allah cares for, and for whom this was predetermined in the Presence of His Witnessing (*hadrat ishhad*). Thus, when he is informed, he knows that the Divinity (*al-uluhiyya*) granted this division, and that it is from the subtleties (*raqa’iq*) of the Eternal (*al-Qadim*). So Glory be to Him, than whom there is no Doer (*fa’il*) besides Him, and no Existent (*mawjud*) for Himself except Him. <<والله خَلَقَكُمْ وما تَعْمَلُونَ>> (And Allah created you and what you do). <<ولا يُسْأَلُ عَمَّا يَفْعَلُ وهُمْ يُسْأَلُونَ>> (He is not questioned about what He does, but they will be questioned). <<فَلِلَّهِ الْحُجَّةُ الْبالِغَةُ فَلَوْ شاءَ لَهَداكُمْ أَجْمَعِينَ>> (So to Allah belongs the conclusive argument. If He had willed, He would have guided you all).

### The Second Testimony

Just as I have called Allah, His angels, and all His creation, and you, to witness my affirmation of His Unity (*tawhid*), so too do I call Him the Glorious, His angels, all His creation, and you, to witness my faith (*iman*) in the one He chose, selected, and elected from that Existence (*wujud*): our Master Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), whom He sent to all mankind universally, <<بَشِيراً ونَذِيراً وداعِياً إِلَى الله بِإِذْنِهِ وسِراجاً مُنِيراً>> (as a bearer of good tidings and a warner, and one who invites to Allah by His permission, and as an illuminating lamp). He (peace and blessings be upon him) conveyed what was revealed to him from his Lord, fulfilled his trust (*amana*), advised his community (*umma*), and stood during his Farewell Pilgrimage (*Hajjat al-Wada’*) before all his followers who were present. He delivered a sermon, reminded, instilled fear and warned, gave good tidings and warned, promised and threatened, poured down rain and thundered. He did not single out anyone for this reminder, by the permission of the One, the Eternal Refuge (*al-Samad*). Then he asked, "Have I conveyed the message?" They replied, "You have conveyed it, O Messenger of Allah." Then he (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "O Allah, bear witness." I believe in everything he (peace and blessings be upon him) brought, both what I know and what I do not know. Among what he brought is the affirmation that death occurs at a term appointed by Allah, which, when it comes, cannot be delayed. I believe in this with a faith free of doubt or suspicion. Just as I have believed and affirmed that the questioning by the two angels of the grave is true (*haqq*), the punishment of the grave is true, the resurrection of bodies from the graves is true, the presentation before Allah the Exalted is true, the Cistern (*al-Hawd*) is true, the Balance (*al-Mizan*) is true, the scattering of the scrolls (*tatawur al-suhuf*) is true, the Bridge (*al-Sirat*) is true, Paradise (*al-Janna*) is true, and the Fire (*al-Nar*) is true, and that a group will be in Paradise and a group in the Fire is true. The distress of that Day is true for one group, while another group <<لا يَحْزُنُهُمُ الْفَزَعُ الْأَكْبَرُ>> (will not be grieved by the greatest terror). The intercession (*shafa’a*) of the angels, the prophets, and the believers, and the removal from the Fire by the Most Merciful of the Merciful of whom He wills after the intercession, is true. The entry of a group of believing perpetrators of major sins (*ahl al-kaba’ir*) into Hell (*Jahannam*) and their subsequent exit through intercession and grace (*al-imtinan*) is true. The eternity (*al-ta’bid*) of the believers and monotheists (*al-muwahhidin*) in the everlasting bliss of the Gardens (*al-Jinan*) is true. The eternity of the people of the Fire in the Fire is true. And everything brought by the Books and the Messengers from Allah, whether known or unknown, is true. This is my testimony concerning myself, a trust with everyone whom it reaches, that he should convey it if asked, wherever he may be. May Allah benefit us and you with this faith, and establish us upon it during the transition from this abode to the Abode of Life (*al-Dar al-Hayawan*), and settle us therein in the Abode of Generosity and Pleasure (*Dar al-Karama wa al-Ridwan*), and separate us from the abode whose garments are made of pitch. May He make us among the company who receive their books with faith, who return from the Cistern fully quenched, whose Balance is heavy, and whose feet are firm upon the Bridge (*al-Sirat*). Indeed, He is the Bestower, the Benefactor. <<فَالْحَمْدُ لِلَّهِ الَّذِي هَدانا لِهذا وما كُنَّا لِنَهْتَدِيَ لَوْ لا أَنْ هَدانَا الله لَقَدْ جاءَتْ رُسُلُ رَبِّنا بِالْحَقِّ>> (So praise is to Allah, who has guided us to this; and we would not have been guided had not Allah guided us. Certainly, the messengers of our Lord came with the truth). "This is the summarized and concise creed of the common people (*al-’awam*) of Islam, both the followers of tradition (*ahl al-taqlid*) and the people of speculation (*ahl al-nazar*)." I shall follow this, God willing, with the creed of the aspiring novice (*al-nashi’a al-shadiya*), which I have included as an abbreviation of the *Iqtisad* (Moderation) in the most concise expression, drawing attention therein to the sources of the proofs (*adillah*) for this religion, using rhymed prose (*masju’a al-alfaz*). I have named it *Risalat al-Ma’lum min ‘Aqa’id Ahl al-Rusum* (The Epistle of the Known from the Creeds of the People of Conventional Forms), to make it easy for the student to memorize. Then I shall follow it with the creed of the elite among the People of Allah (*khawass ahl Allah*), the people of the Path (*tariq*)—the Verifiers (*al-muhaqqiqin*), the People of Unveiling (*al-Kashf*) and Existence (*al-Wujud*). I have also isolated this in another section which I named *Al-Ma’rifa* (Gnosis). With this, the introduction of the book concludes. As for the explicit declaration of the creed of the Quintessence (*al-khulasa*), I have not dedicated a specific section to it due to its obscurity, but I have presented it scattered throughout the chapters of this book, fully detailed and explained. However, as mentioned, it is dispersed. Whoever is granted understanding by Allah will know its matter and distinguish it from others, for it is the True Knowledge (*al-’ilm al-haqq*) and the Veriest Saying (*al-qawl al-sidq*). There is no goal beyond it. The sighted and the blind are equal in it. It joins the distant to the near and welds the low to the high. Allah is the Granter of Success; there is no Lord other than Him.

### (Section: The Creed of the Aspiring Novice and the Student)

The student (*al-Shadi*) said: Four scholars gathered in the dome of Arin, beneath the equator. One was Maghrebi (Western), the second Mashriqi (Eastern), the third Shami (Syrian), and the fourth Yamani (Yemeni). They discussed the sciences and the difference between Names (*al-Asma’*) and conventional Forms (*al-Rusum*). Each of them said to his companion: "There is no good in knowledge that does not grant its possessor eternal happiness, nor sanctify its bearer from the influence of time (*al-amad*). Let us search among these sciences we possess for the knowledge that is the most precious thing sought, the best thing acquired, the most sublime thing stored, and the greatest thing to boast of." The Maghrebi said: "I possess the knowledge of the Self-Subsisting Bearer (*al-hamil al-qa’im*)." The Mashriqi said: "I possess the knowledge of the Necessary Borne Bearer (*al-hamil al-mahmul al-lazim*)." The Shami said: "I possess the knowledge of Origination (*al-ibda’*) and Composition (*al-tarkib*)." The Yamani said: "I possess the knowledge of Summarization (*al-takhliṣ*) and Arrangement (*al-tartib*)." Then they said: "Let each of us reveal what he has comprehended and unveil the reality of what he claims."

### (Chapter One: On the Knowledge of the Self-Subsisting Bearer, in the Western Dialect)

The Maghrebi Imam stood and said: "I have precedence due to the rank of my knowledge, so the judgment concerning first principles is mine." The attendees said to him: "Speak, be concise, and be the eloquent one who performs a miracle."

[Chapter: The Contingent Event (*al-Hadith*) Has a Cause]
