He said: Know that whatever was not, then came to be, and for which times are equal in relation to it, requires an Originator (*al-Mukawwin*) immediately.

[Chapter: The Ruling on That Which is Never Free of Contingent Events]

Then he said: Everything that cannot dispense with a certain matter, its ruling is the ruling of that matter. However, if it belongs to the world of creation (*al-khalq*) and command (*al-amr*), the seeker should direct his attention to it and the researcher should rely upon it.

[Chapter: Subsistence (*al-Baqa’*) and the Non-Existence of the Eternal (*al-Qadim*)]

Then he said: That for which Existence (*al-Wujud*) is necessary, its non-existence is impossible. And that which came to be but was not, its eternity (*qidam*) is impossible. If non-existence were not impossible for it, then its opposite would be valid in eternity. If the opposite was not, then incapacity is inherent in the opposite. And if it was, then it is impossible for this other to have been. It is impossible for it to cease by its own essence, due to the soundness of the condition and the firmness of the connection.

[Chapter: Latency (*al-Kumun*) and Manifestation (*al-Zuhur*)]

Then he said: Everything whose essence (*‘ayn*) is manifest but does not necessitate a ruling, its being manifest is impossible, for it yields no knowledge.

[Chapter: Invalidating the Transference of the Accident (*al-’Arad*) and its Non-Existence by Itself]

Then he said: It is impossible for it to inhabit places, because its journey is in the second moment of its own existence, and it is not a resident. If it were permissible for it to transfer, it would subsist by itself and dispense with a locus (*al-mahall*). Neither an opposite can annihilate it, due to its characteristic of being lost, nor can the Agent (*al-Fa’il*), for no rational person would say, "He acted upon nothing."

[Chapter: Invalidating Contingent Events Without a Beginning]

Then he said: That whose existence depends on the annihilation of something else has no existence until that thing is annihilated. If it exists, then that thing upon which it depended has been annihilated, and the meaning is attained. Whoever is preceded by something is confined below it, restricted, and bound by this description. Even if it were eternalized, the essence (*al-’ayn*) would be established with two *lams*.

[Chapter: Eternity (*al-Qidam*)]

Then he said: If the ruling of the subject (*al-musnad ilayh*) were the ruling of the predicate (*al-musnad*), the number would not terminate, and the existence of what exists would not be valid.

[Chapter: Not a Substance (*Jawhar*)]

Then he said: If what we have established were emptied and filled, it would decay and not decay.

[Chapter: Not a Body (*Jism*)]

Then he said: If it accepted composition (*al-tarkib*), it would dissolve; or if it accepted combination (*al-ta’lif*), it would disintegrate. And if similarity occurs, distinction falls away.

[Chapter: Not an Accident (*‘Arad*)]

Then he said: If its existence required something else to subsist in, that other thing would not be dependent upon it. Yet its dependence upon Him is sound, so it is false that its existence should depend on it, when its origination has already conditioned it. Furthermore, describing the description is impossible, so there is absolutely no way to this conviction (*‘aqd*).

[Chapter: Negation of Directions (*al-Jihat*)]

Then he said: Although the sphere (*al-kura*) is perishable, it is not possessed of a side. If directions are towards me, their ruling is upon me, and I am outside of them. He was, and I was not. So why the clamor and the trouble?

[Chapter: Establishment (*al-Istiwa’*)]

Then he said: Everyone who settles in a place is subject to departure from it, and his transference is established. Whoever aligns himself essentially with something, the concept of three-dimensionality (*al-tathlith*) limits and measures him. This contradicts what the intellect previously affirmed.

[Chapter: Oneness (*al-Ahadiyya*)]

Then he said: If nothing existed except through two independent entities, whether in agreement or disagreement, we would not see separation or union in Existence (*al-Wujud*). The ruling of the hypothetical is the ruling of the actual. Therefore, hypothesis is not beneficial here for the disputant.

[Chapter: On Vision (*al-Ru’ya*)]

Then he said: If a thing exists in its essence (*‘ayn*), it is permissible for the possessor of the eye to see it with his eye, conditioned by its manifest aspect and its socket. There is no cause that necessitates vision in the doctrine of most Ash’aris except Existence (*al-Wujud*), whether with structure or without structure, though structure is necessary. If vision were to affect the object seen, we would deem it impossible. Thus, the objectives have become clear through their proofs, as we have mentioned. Then he offered prayers and salutations after praising Allah and sat down. The attendees thanked him for his conciseness in expression and his comprehensive coverage of meanings through subtle indication.

### (Chapter Two: On the Knowledge of the Necessary Borne Bearer, in the Eastern Dialect)

[Chapter: Power (*al-Qudra*)]

Then the Mashriqi stood and said: The formation of a thing from a thing is inclination, but the formation of a thing from nothing is the capability (*iqtidar*) of the Eternal (*al-Azal*). And whoever does not resist you, your Power is effective in him and has always been so.

[Chapter: Knowledge (*al-’Ilm*)]

Then he said: The origination of rulings in a firmly established entity proves, by its ruling, the existence of the Knowledge of the Establisher.

[Chapter: Life (*al-Hayat*)]

Then he said: And Life (*al-Hayat*) in the cosmos (*al-’alam*) is a necessary condition and a subsisting attribute.

[Chapter: Will (*al-Irada*)]

Then he said: When a thing accepts precedence and avoidance, there must be a Specifier (*mukhasis*) for the occurrence of specification (*ikhtisas*). This is the very essence of Will (*al-Irada*) according to rational judgment and custom.

[Chapter: Contingent Will (*al-Irada al-Haditha*)]

Then he said: If the Willer were to will something that was not, then what was not would be willed by what was not.

[Chapter: Will Not in a Locus]

Then he said: It is impossible for meanings (*al-ma’ani*) to necessitate their rulings in anything other than that in which they subsist, so pay attention.

[Chapter: Speech (*al-Kalam*)]

Then he said: Whoever speaks to himself about what has passed, that speech is not Will (*irada*). By this, the proof has judged and decreed concerning Speech.

[Chapter: Eternity of Knowledge (*Qidam al-’Ilm*)]

Then he said: The Eternal (*al-Qadim*) does not accept the contingent, so do not dispute. If He were to originate in Himself what is not from Himself, He would be deficient due to the absence of that attribute. And whoever’s perfection is established by reason and text cannot be attributed with deficiency.

[Chapter: Hearing and Sight (*al-Sam’ wa al-Basar*)]

Then he said: If He did not see you and did not hear you, He would be ignorant of much about you, and attributing ignorance to Him is impossible. Therefore, there is absolutely no way to negate these two Attributes from Him. Whoever ventures to negate them ventures into something fearful, as it leads to His being afflicted.

[Chapter: Affirmation of the Attributes (*al-Sifat*)]

Then he said: It is necessary for a ruling to be necessitated by a meaning, just as it is necessary for a meaning that does not subsist by itself to require a self-sufficient entity. O disputant, why do you exert yourself so much? That is only due to your fear of number (*al-’adad*), yet this does not invalidate the reality of the One and the Unique (*al-Ahad*). If you knew that number is the Unique, you would not have engaged in dispute with anyone. Thus, I have clarified the Borne Bearer, the contingent and the necessary, in the divisions of these signs. Then he sat down.

### (Chapter Three: On the Knowledge of Origination and Composition, in the Syrian Dialect)

[Chapter: The Cosmos (*al-’Alam*) is the Creation of Allah]

Then the Shami stood and said: If contingent events (*al-muhdathat*) are similar, and the relation of Power (*al-qudra*) to them is merely due to the Essence (*al-Dhat*), then by what proof is some of the possible (*al-mumkinat*) excluded from it?

[Chapter: Acquisition (*al-Kasb*)]

Then he said: Since the Will (*al-Irada*) truly relates to what is willed, and the contingent Power (*al-qudra al-haditha*) is not like it due to a flaw in the method, that is Acquisition (*al-Kasb*). Thus, the acquisition is the servant’s, and the decree is the Lord’s. This is clarified by the difference between voluntary movement and involuntary trembling.

[Chapter: Acquisition is Willed by Allah]

Then he said: The condition of Power is origination, provided Knowledge and Will assist it. Beware of custom! Everything that leads to the deficiency of Divinity (*al-uluhiyya*) is rejected. Whoever posits in contingent Existence (*al-wujud al-hadith*) something that is not willed by Allah is banished from Gnosis (*al-Ma’rifa*), and the door of Unity (*al-Tawhid*) is closed in his face. Sometimes the command (*al-amr*) is willed, but the object of the command (*al-ma’mur bihi*) is not willed—this is the correct view, and this is the utmost clarity.

[Chapter: The Creation of the Cosmos is Not Obligatory]

Then he said: Whoever makes something obligatory upon Allah has imposed upon Him the limit of the necessary (*al-wajib*), and that is impossible for Allah according to sound doctrines. Whoever posits obligation due to prior Knowledge has departed from the ruling known among scholars concerning the necessary, although the ruling itself is sound.

[Chapter: Imposing an Obligation Beyond Capacity (*Taklif ma la yutaq*)]

Then he said: Imposing an obligation beyond capacity is rationally permissible, and we have witnessed this both observationally and through transmission.

[Chapter: Causing Pain to the Innocent is Not Injustice in Relation to Allah]

Then he said: He from whose dominion nothing truly departs cannot be characterized by tyranny (*jawr*) or injustice (*zulm*) in the judgment He executes within His dominion.

[Chapter: Goodness (*al-Husn*) and Ugliness (*al-Qubh*)]

Then he said: Whoever is a free agent (*mukhtar*) is not obligated to observe what is most beneficial (*al-aslah*). This is established and sound. The determination of ugliness and goodness is by the Law (*al-Shar’*) and the purpose (*al-gharad*). Whoever says that goodness and ugliness are inherent in the essence of the good and the ugly is a person afflicted by ignorance.

[Chapter: The Obligation of Knowing Allah]

Then he said: If the obligation of knowing Allah and other matters is conditioned by the connection of harm to its abandonment in the future, then the obligation is not valid by reason, because reason does not comprehend it.

[Chapter: Sending the Messengers (*Ba’that al-Rusul*)]

Then he said: If the intellect is independent in one matter but not independent in another, there must be an independent conveyor to it. Thus, the sending of Messengers is not impossible, and they are the most knowledgeable of creation concerning goals and paths.

[Chapter: Affirming the Message of a Specific Messenger]

Then he said: If it were permissible for the liar to bring what the truthful one brought, realities (*al-haqa’iq*) would be inverted, Power (*al-qudra*) would be exchanged for incapacity, and falsehood would be attributed to the Presence of Glory (*hadrat al-’Izz*). All this is impossible and the height of misguidance. By that which establishes the First One, the second is established in all aspects and meanings.

### (Chapter Four: On the Knowledge of Summarization and Arrangement, in the Yemeni Dialect)

[Chapter: Re-creation (*al-I’ada*)]

Then the Yamani stood and said: Whoever destroys something after having originated it, it is permissible for him to re-create it just as He began it.

[Chapter: The Questioning and Punishment of the Grave]

Then he said: When the spiritual subtlety (*al-latifa al-ruhaniyya*) subsists in any part of the human being, the name "living creature" (*al-hayawan*) is validly applied to him. The sleeper sees what the awake person beside him does not see, due to the difference in their states. Whoever is sustained by life is subject to pleasure and pain. Why do you not commit to this?

[Chapter: The Balance (*al-Mizan*)]

Then he said: The substitute for a thing takes its place and necessitates its rulings for it.

[Chapter: The Bridge (*al-Sirat*)]

Then he said: Whoever is capable of holding birds in the air, which are bodies (*ajsam*), is capable of holding all bodies.

[Chapter: The Creation of Paradise and the Fire]

Then he said: The creation (*al-nash’a*) is already complete, and the edges of the circle have met before the circle itself has fully manifested.

[Chapter: The Obligation of the Imamate (*al-Imama*)]

Then he said: Establishing the religion (*al-din*) is the objective, and this is not valid except through security (*al-aman*). Therefore, the appointment of an Imam is obligatory in every age.

[Chapter: Conditions of the Imamate]

Then he said: When the conditions are complete, the contract is valid, and the world is obligated to fulfill the covenant. These conditions are: being male, puberty, intellect, knowledge, freedom, piety (*wara’*), courage (*najda*), competence (*kifaya*), lineage from Quraysh, and the soundness of the senses of hearing and sight. This is the view of some people of knowledge and speculation (*al-nazar*).

[Chapter: When Two Imams Contradict Each Other]

Then he said: If two Imams contradict each other, the contract belongs to the one with the greater following. If it is impossible to depose a deficient Imam due to the certainty of widespread corruption occurring, then maintaining the contract with him is obligatory, and his removal is not permissible. The student (*al-Shadi*) said: Thus, each of the four fulfilled what he stipulated, and Existence (*al-Wujud*) became ordered and connected.

### (Section: On the Creed of the People of Specialization from the People of Allah, between Speculation and Unveiling)

Praise be to Allah, who bewilders the intellects in the results of their aspirations. And peace and blessings be upon Muhammad and his family.

[Question: The Limit of Intellects]

To proceed: Intellects (*al-’uqul*) have a limit at which they stop, insofar as they are reflective, not insofar as they are receptive. Thus, we say concerning a matter that is rationally impossible, it may not be impossible in a Divine relation (*nisba ilahiyya*); just as we say concerning a matter that is rationally permissible, it may be impossible in a Divine relation.

[Question: The Suitability between the Necessary and the Possible]

What suitability exists between the Real (*al-Haqq*), the Necessary of Existence (*al-Wajib al-Wujud*) by His Essence (*Dhat*), and the possible (*al-mumkin*), even if it is necessary through Him, according to those who hold this view due to the requirement of the Essence or the requirement of Knowledge? The intellectual premises for this are only sound when derived from existential proofs (*al-barahin al-wujudiyya*). There must be a common aspect between the proof (*al-dalil*) and the proven (*al-madlul*), and the demonstration (*al-burhan*) and the demonstrated, by which the connection is established, having a relation to the proof and a relation to the object proven by that proof. Were it not for that common aspect, no indicator would ever lead to the object indicated by its proof. Therefore, it is never valid for creation (*al-khalq*) and the Real (*al-Haqq*) to meet in a single aspect insofar as the Essence (*al-Dhat*) is concerned. However, insofar as this Essence is described by Divinity (*al-uluhiyya*), this is another ruling that intellects are independent in grasping. Everything that the intellect is independent in grasping, in our view, can have knowledge of it precede its witnessing (*shuhud*). But the Essence (*Dhat*) of the Real the Exalted is distinct from this ruling, for the witnessing of it precedes the knowledge of it; rather, it is witnessed but not known, just as the Divinity (*al-uluhiyya*) is known but not witnessed, and the Essence is its counterpart. How many rational people, who claim sound intellect among the speculative scholars (*al-’ulama’ al-nuzzar*), say that they have attained the knowledge of the Essence through intellectual speculation, yet they are mistaken in this, because their thought oscillates between negation (*salb*) and affirmation (*ithbat*). Affirmation returns to the observer, for the observer only affirms for the Real what the observer is upon, such as being Knowing, Powerful, Willing, and all the Names (*al-Asma’*). Negation returns to non-existence (*al-’adam*) and denial, and denial cannot be an essential attribute (*sifa dhatiyya*), because the essential attributes of existent things are affirmative. Thus, this thinker, oscillating between affirmation and negation, has attained nothing of the knowledge of Allah.

[Question: The Knowledge of the Conditioned by the Absolute]

How can the conditioned (*al-muqayyad*) attain knowledge of the Absolute (*al-mutlaq*), when its essence does not necessitate it? And how can the possible (*al-mumkin*) reach the knowledge of the Necessary by Essence (*al-Wajib bi al-Dhat*), when every aspect of the possible is subject to non-existence, decay, and need? If an aspect were to unite the Necessary by Essence and the possible, then the Necessary would be subject to what the possible is subject to in that aspect, namely decay and need. This is impossible concerning the Necessary. Therefore, establishing a unifying aspect between the Necessary and the possible is impossible, for the aspects of the possible are subordinate to it, and the possible itself is subject to non-existence, so its subordinates are even more deserving of this ruling. And if what is established for the possible were established for the Necessary by Essence through that unifying aspect, and yet nothing is established for the possible insofar as it is established for the Necessary by Essence, then the existence of a unifying aspect between the possible and the Necessary by Essence is impossible.

[Question: Divinity Has Rulings]

However, I say that the Divinity (*al-uluhiyya*) has rulings, even if they are judgments, and it is in the forms of these rulings that the Theophany (*al-Tajalli*) occurs in the Hereafter, wherever it may be. For there is disagreement regarding the Prophet’s (peace be upon him) vision of his Lord, as mentioned. And the hadith of the Greatest Light (*al-Nur al-A’zam*) on the cushion of pearls and rubies, and other such reports, has come down.

[Question: Will (*al-Irada*) and Choice (*al-Ikhtiyar*)]

I affirm the ruling of Will (*al-hukm al-iradi*), but I do not affirm Choice (*al-ikhtiyar*). For the discourse concerning Choice, as it is transmitted, only arises from looking at the possible (*al-mumkin*) stripped of its cause and causality.

[Question: Allah Was, and Nothing Was With Him]

I affirm, based on the protective Unveiling (*al-Kashf al-I’tisami*), that Allah was, and nothing was with Him. The Prophet’s (peace be upon him) wording ends here. What follows this is interpolated, namely their saying, "And He is now as He was." They mean in the ruling. Thus, "now" and "was" are two matters that revert to us, for they appeared through us, and their likes. The suitability has been negated. That which is referred to by "Allah was, and nothing was with Him" is the Divinity (*al-uluhiyya*), not the Essence (*al-Dhat*). Every ruling established for the Essence in the domain of Divine Knowledge is only for the Divinity, and these are rulings of relations (*nisab*), attributions (*idafat*), and negations (*sulub*). Thus, multiplicity (*al-kathra*) is in the relations, not in the Essence (*al-’ayn*). It is here that the feet of those who associated partners between that which accepts anthropomorphism (*al-tashbih*) and that which does not, slipped when discussing the Attributes (*al-Sifat*). They relied in this upon unifying matters—namely, the proof, the reality, the cause, and the condition—and judged by them concerning the unseen and the witnessed. As for the witnessed, it may be conceded, but as for the unseen, it is not conceded.

[Question: The Sea of the Cloud (*Bahr al-’Ama’*)]

The Sea of the Cloud (*Bahr al-’Ama’*) is an Isthmus (*Barzakh*) between the Real (*al-Haqq*) and creation (*al-khalq*). In this sea, the possible (*al-mumkin*) is described as Knowing and Powerful, and by all the Divine Names (*al-Asma’ al-Ilahiyya*) that we possess. And the Real is described by wonder, smiling, laughter, joy, and companionship (*al-ma’iyya*), and most of the cosmic descriptions. So return what belongs to Him and take what belongs to you. To Him belongs the Descent (*al-Nuzul*), and to us belongs the Ascent (*al-Mi’raj*).

[Question: Reaching Him Through Him and Through You]

The one you wish to reach, you only reach Him through Him and through you: through you, insofar as your seeking is concerned, and through Him, because He is the object of your intention. The Divinity (*al-uluhiyya*) seeks that, but the Essence (*al-Dhat*) does not seek it.

[Question: That Which is Directed Towards Origination]

That which is directed towards the origination of everything other than Allah the Exalted is the Divinity (*al-uluhiyya*) with its rulings, relations, and attributions. It is the Divinity that necessitated the effects (*al-athar*), for a Dominator (*qahir*) without a dominated, and a Powerful One (*qadir*) without a capable object, is impossible in terms of potentiality, existence, power, and action.

[Question: The Most Specific Description of Divinity]

The specific, most specific description (*al-na’t al-akhass*) by which the Divinity (*al-uluhiyya*) is uniquely characterized is its being Powerful (*qadira*), for the possible (*al-mumkin*) has no power whatsoever. Rather, it has the capacity to accept the relation of the Divine effect to it.

[Question: Acquisition (*al-Kasb*)]

Acquisition (*al-Kasb*) is the relation of the possible’s will to a specific action rather than another, which the Divine Capability (*al-iqtidar al-ilahi*) brings into existence upon this relation. This is therefore called acquisition for the possible.

[Question: Compulsion (*al-Jabr*)]

Compulsion (*al-Jabr*) is not valid according to the Verifier (*al-muhaqqiq*) because it contradicts the validity of the servant’s action. Compulsion is forcing the possible to act despite the possible’s refusal. The inanimate object (*al-jamad*) is not compelled because no action can be conceived from it, nor does it possess ordinary intellect. The possible is not compelled because no action can be conceived from it, nor does it possess verified intellect, despite the appearance of effects from it.

[Question: Affliction and Well-being in the Cosmos]

The Divinity (*al-uluhiyya*) decrees that there be affliction (*bala’*) and well-being (*’afiya*) in the cosmos. The removal of the Avenger (*al-Muntaqim*) from Existence is no more appropriate than the removal of the Forgiver, the Possessor of Pardon, and the Bestower. If any of the Names remained without a ruling, it would be rendered inactive (*mu’attal*), and rendering the Divinity inactive is impossible. Thus, the absence of the effect of the Names is impossible.

[Question: The Perceiver (*al-Mudrik*) and the Perceived (*al-Mudrak*)]

The Perceiver and the Perceived are each of two types. A perceiver who knows and has the power of imagination (*quwwat al-takhayyul*), and a perceiver who knows but does not have the power of imagination. The perceived (with a *fatha* on the *ra’*) is of two types: a perceived object that has a form, which is known in its form by one who does not have the power of imagination and does not conceive it, and is known and conceived by one who has the power of imagination; and a perceived object that has no form, which is only known.

[Question: Knowledge (*al-’Ilm*)]

Knowledge is neither the conception (*tasawwur*) of the known object (*al-ma’lum*) nor the meaning by which the known object is conceived. For not every known object is conceived, nor does every knower conceive. Conception for the knower only arises from his being imaginative (*mutakhayyil*). The form (*sura*) for the known object is that it be in a state that the imagination can grasp. Yet there are known objects that the imagination cannot grasp at all, proving that they have no form.

[Question: Action from the Possible]

If action were valid for the possible, it would be valid for it to be powerful, yet it has no action, so it has no power. Therefore, affirming power for the possible is a claim without proof. Our discussion in this chapter is with the Ash’aris who affirm power for the possible while negating action from it.

[Question: Only One Proceeds from the One in All Aspects]

Only one proceeds from the One in all aspects. Whether there is anything characterized by this description or not is a matter for the impartial to consider. Do you not see that the Ash’aris only attribute origination (*al-ijad*) to the Real based on His being Powerful, specification (*al-ikhtisas*) based on His being Willing, and rulings based on His being Knowing? And the state of being Willing is not the very essence of the state of being Powerful. Therefore, their subsequent statement that He is One in all aspects is not sound concerning the general relation. How can it be, when they affirm Attributes (*al-Sifat*) that are additional to the Essence (*al-Dhat*) and subsist in Him the Exalted? The same applies to those who affirm relations (*nisab*) and attributions (*idafat*). No group has achieved Unity (*al-wahda*) in all aspects, except that they are either compelled by their doctrine to deny it or they affirm it. The affirmation of Unity (*al-wahdaniyya*) is only in the Divinity, meaning *La ilaha illa Huwa* (There is no god but He), and that is sound and demonstrated.

[Question: Attributes are Relations and Attributions]

The Creator’s being Knowing, Living, Powerful, and all the other Attributes, are relations (*nisab*) and attributions (*idafat*) to Him, not additional essences (*a’yan za’ida*), because that would lead to describing Him with deficiency. For the one who is perfect by an addition is essentially deficient without that addition, whereas He is perfect by His Essence. Therefore, an addition essentially upon the Essence is impossible, but by relations and attributions, it is not impossible. As for the saying of the one who claims, "They are neither Him nor are they others than Him," this is an extremely remote statement. For the proponent of this doctrine has indicated the affirmation of an addition, which is undoubtedly an other (*ghayr*); he merely denied the application of that term. Then he arbitrarily defined the limit by saying that two others (*al-ghayran*) are those for whom separation from one another is permissible in place, time, existence, and non-existence. This is not the definition of two others according to all scholars of this matter.

[Question: Unity and the Multiplicity of Relations]

The multiplicity of relations (*ta’alluqat*) from the relating entity does not affect its being one in itself, just as the division of what is spoken does not affect the Oneness (*ahadiyya*) of Speech (*al-Kalam*).

[Question: Multiplicity of Essential Attributes]

Even if the essential Attributes (*al-sifat al-dhatiyya*) of the described entity are multiple, they do not indicate the multiplicity of the described entity in itself, because they are the totality of His Essence, even if they are rationally distinguishable from one another.

[Question: Forms of Knowledge and Substance]

Every form (*sura*) in the cosmos (*al-’alam*) is an accident (*’arad*) in the substance (*jawhar*). It is upon this accident that stripping and removal occur, while the substance is one. The division is in the form, not in the substance.

[Question: Multiplicity in the First Effect (*al-Ma’lul al-Awwal*)]

Concerning the saying of the one who claims that multiplicity only arose from the First Effect, even though it is one, because three considerations were found in it—namely, its cause, its self, and its possibility—we say to them: This necessitates the same for the First Cause, meaning the existence of considerations in it while it is one. Why, then, did you prevent that only one should proceed from it? You must either commit to the proceeding of multiplicity from the First Cause, or the proceeding of one from the First Effect, and you do not affirm either of the two.

[Question: Negating Causality from the Divine Essence]

He for whom essential perfection (*al-kamal al-dhati*) and essential self-sufficiency (*al-ghina al-dhati*) are necessary cannot be a cause (*’illa*) for anything, because His being a cause would lead to His dependence on the effect (*al-ma’lul*), and the Essence is transcendent above dependence on anything. Therefore, His being a cause is impossible. However, the Divinity (*al-uluhiyya*) may accept attributions (*idafat*). If it is said that *al-Ilah* (God) is only applied to one who is perfect in Essence, self-sufficient in Essence, and does not desire attribution or relation, we say: There is no dispute over the wording, unlike the term *al-’illa* (cause), which, in its original meaning and definition, necessitates an effect. If by *al-’illa* is meant what this person means by *al-Ilah*, then it is conceded, and the only remaining dispute over this term is whether the Law (*al-Shar’*) prohibits it, permits it, or remains silent.

[Question: The Secret of Divinity]

Divinity (*al-uluhiyya*) is a level (*martaba*) for the Essence (*al-Dhat*) that only Allah deserves. It sought what is its seeking, and the worshipped (*al-ma’luh*) seeks it, and it seeks him. The Essence is self-sufficient of everything. If this binding secret (*al-sirr al-rabit*) were to become manifest—in the sense of being removed, as one says, "They departed (*zaharū*) from the town," meaning they left it—Divinity would be nullified, but the perfection of the Essence would not be nullified. This is the saying of the Imam: "Divinity has a secret; if it were to become manifest, Divinity would be nullified."

[Question: Knowledge, the Known, and Relation]

Knowledge (*al-’ilm*) does not change with the change of the known object (*al-ma’lum*), but the relation (*al-ta’alluq*) changes. The relation is an attribution to a specific known object. For example, the relation of Knowledge that Zayd will be, then he was. The relation of Knowledge is now to his being existent in the present, and the relation of Knowledge to his future existence has ceased. The change of the relation does not necessitate the change of Knowledge. Likewise, the change of what is heard or seen does not necessitate the change of sight or hearing.

[Question: The Known Object of Knowledge]

It is established that Knowledge does not change, so the known object also does not change. For the known object of Knowledge is only a relation between two verified known matters. The body (*al-jism*) is a known object that never changes, and standing (*al-qiyam*) is a known object that does not change. The relation of standing to the body is the known object to which change is attributed. The relation also does not change. This specific relation (*al-nisba al-shakhsiyya*) also does not belong to anyone other than this specific person, so it does not change. There is absolutely no known object besides these four: the three verified matters (the relation, the related, and the related-to) and the specific relation. If it is said that we only attribute change to the related-to because we saw it in one state and then saw it in another state, we reply: When you looked at the related-to as a certain matter, you did not look at it from the perspective of its reality, for its reality is unchanging, nor from the perspective of its being related-to, for that reality is also unchanging. Rather, you looked at it from the perspective of its being related-to in a certain state. Therefore, the other known object is not the related-to in that state which you said ceased, for it does not depart from its relatedness. Rather, this is another related-to with another relation to it. Thus, neither Knowledge nor the known object changes. Rather, Knowledge has relations to the known objects, or a relation to the known objects, as you wish.

[Question: Conceptual Knowledge (*al-’Ilm al-Tasawwuri*)]

Nothing of conceptual knowledge (*al-’ilm al-tasawwuri*) is acquired through intellectual speculation (*al-nazar al-fikri*). Acquired knowledge is nothing but the relation of a conceptual known object to another conceptual known object. The absolute relation is also part of conceptual knowledge. If you attribute acquisition to conceptual knowledge, this is only because you hear a term that a certain group has conventionally agreed upon for a certain meaning that everyone knows, but not everyone knows that this term indicates it. Therefore, one asks about the meaning to which this term was applied—what meaning is it? The one asked specifies it for him with what he knows. If the questioner did not already possess knowledge of that meaning, in terms of its meaningfulness and the indication that leads to knowing what that person intended by that convention for that meaning, he would not have accepted it or understood what was said. Therefore, all meanings must be inherent in the soul, and then they are unveiled to him gradually, state after state.

[Question: Describing Knowledge with Comprehension (*al-Ihata*)]

Describing Knowledge with comprehension (*al-ihata*) of the known objects necessitates their finitude, and finitude in them is impossible. Therefore, comprehension is impossible. However, it is said that Knowledge encompasses the reality (*haqiqa*) of every known object. Otherwise, it is not known by way of comprehension. For whoever knows a matter from one aspect and not from all aspects has not encompassed it.

[Question: Vision of Insight and Vision of the Eye]

The vision of insight (*ru’yat al-basira*) is knowledge, and the vision of the eye (*ru’yat al-basar*) is a path to the attainment of knowledge. Thus, the God’s being Hearing and Seeing is a detailed relation (*ta’alluq tafsili*). They are two rulings of Knowledge, and the duality occurs because of the related object, which is the heard and the seen.

[Question: Eternity (*al-Azal*)]

Eternity (*al-Azal*) is a negative description (*na’t salbi*), which is the negation of firstness (*al-awwaliyya*). If we say "First" concerning the Divinity, it refers only to the rank (*al-martaba*).

[Question: The Contingency of Everything Other Than Allah According to the Ash’aris]

The Ash’aris demonstrated the contingency (*huduth*) of everything other than Allah by the contingency of localized entities (*al-mutahayyizāt*) and the contingency of their accidents (*a’rad*). This is not sound unless they establish proof that everything other than Allah the Exalted is confined to what they mentioned. We concede the contingency of what they mentioned as contingent.

[Question: Non-Localized Existence (*al-Wujud al-La-Mutahayyiz*)]

Every existent entity subsisting by itself that is non-localized is possible (*mumkin*). Times do not run alongside its existence, nor do places seek it.

[Question: The First Possible According to the Ash’aris]

The Ash’ari’s proof concerning the First Possible is that its precedence over the time of its existence and its delay after it are permissible. Time, in this issue according to him, is estimated (*muqaddar*), not existent. Thus, specification (*al-ikhtisas*) is proof of a Specifier (*al-mukhasis*). This is a flawed proof due to the non-existence of time, so it is invalid as a proof. If he had said: The relation of the possible things to Existence, or the relation of Existence to the possible things, is a single relation insofar as it is a relation, not insofar as it is possible. Therefore, the specification of some possible things with Existence, excluding others, is proof that they have a Specifier. This is the very essence of the contingency of everything other than Allah.

[Question: Time (*al-Zaman*)]

The saying of the one who claims that time is an imagined duration (*mudda mutawahhama*) traversed by the movement of the celestial sphere (*al-falak*) is flawed speech, because the imagined is not a verified existence. They criticize the Ash’aris for estimating time in the First Possible, so the movements of the celestial sphere traverse nothing. If another says that time is the movement of the celestial sphere, and the sphere is localized, then movement can only traverse what is localized.

[Question: The Ambiguous Term (*al-Lafz al-Mushtarak*) According to the Ash’aris and the Anthropomorphists (*al-Mujassima*)]

I am astonished by two large groups, the Ash’aris and the Anthropomorphists, in their error concerning the ambiguous term (*al-lafz al-mushtarak*). How did they make it a basis for anthropomorphism (*tashbih*)? Anthropomorphism only occurs through the word "like" (*mithl*) or the *kaf* of comparison (*kaf al-sifa*) between two things in the language. This is rarely found in anything they deem anthropomorphic, whether it be a verse or a report. Furthermore, the Ash’aris imagined that by interpreting (*ta’awwala*), they had escaped anthropomorphism, yet they did not leave it. They merely moved from anthropomorphism with bodies (*al-ajsam*) to anthropomorphism with contingent meanings (*al-ma’ani al-muhdatha*) that differ from the eternal descriptions in reality and definition. Thus, they did not move away from anthropomorphism with contingent things at all. If we were to adopt their view, we would not, for example, shift the meaning of *al-Istiwa’* (establishment) from settlement (*al-istiqrar*) to domination (*al-istila’*), as they did, especially since the Throne (*al-’Arsh*) is mentioned in relation to this *Istiwa’*. The meaning of domination is nullified by the mention of the couch/throne, and it is impossible to divert it to another meaning that contradicts settlement. I would say that anthropomorphism, for example, occurred with *al-Istiwa’*, which is a meaning, not with the object upon which the *Istiwa’* occurs, which is the body. *Al-Istiwa’* is a rational, conceptual reality attributed to every essence according to what the reality of that essence dictates. We have no need for the forced interpretation that diverts *al-Istiwa’* from its apparent meaning. This is a clear and undeniable error. As for the Anthropomorphists (*al-Mujassima*), they should not have exceeded the transmitted term to one of its possible meanings, despite their faith and their adherence to His saying the Exalted: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him).

[Question: Abomination (*al-Fahsha’*) and its Inclusion in Divine Decree (*al-Qada’*)]

Just as He the Exalted did not command abomination (*al-fahsha’*), He likewise does not will it, but He decreed it and predestined it (*qaddaraha*). The explanation of His not willing it is that its being an abomination is not its essence; rather, it is Allah’s ruling concerning it. Allah’s ruling concerning things is uncreated, and whatever is not subject to creation is not willed. If we were compelled to affirm His Will for obedience, we would affirm it and say that the Will for obedience is established by transmission (*sam’an*), not by reason (*‘aqlan*). So they affirmed it, and they affirmed it for abomination. We accepted it by faith, just as we accepted the weighing of deeds and their forms, despite their being accidents (*a’rad*). This does not invalidate our position, due to the requirement of the proof.

[Question: The Absolute Non-Existence of the Possible]

The non-existence (العدم) of the contingent entity (الممكن) that precedes its existence by judgment is not intended. However, the non-existence that accompanies it by judgment during its existence—meaning that if existence (الوجود) were not present, that non-existence would apply to it—*that* non-existence is intended during the existence of the contingent entity, due to the possibility of non-existence remaining attached to it. And the non-existence of the contingent entity that is *not* intended is that which stands opposite the existence of the Necessary Being by Essence (الواجب لذاته). This is because the level (مرتبة) of Absolute Existence (الوجود المطلق) stands opposite the absolute non-existence (العدم المطلق) belonging to the contingent entity, since the contingent entity has no possibility of existence at this level. And this pertains solely to the existence of Divinity (الألوهة).

### Issue: Multiplicity of Eternals

The existence of an eternal (قديم) entity that is not a deity (إله) is not impossible according to reason (العقل). If such an entity does not exist, it is known only through transmitted revelation (السمع).

### Issue: Specification of the Contingent's Existence

The fact that the Specifier (المخصص) wills the existence of a specific contingent entity (ممكن ما) means that the specification is not for its existence merely as existence, but rather for its relation to a specific contingent entity whose relation is permissible to another contingent entity. Therefore, Existence (الوجود), considered absolutely from the perspective of the contingent, and not from the perspective of a specific contingent entity, is neither intended nor actualized at all, except through a specific contingent entity. And if it is through a specific contingent entity, then it is not intended in itself, but only in terms of its relation to that specific contingent entity, and nothing else.

### Issue: The Specifying Cause

The proof (الدليل) indicates the establishment of the Specifying Cause (السبب المخصص). And the proof indicates, for example, the necessity of relying on revelation (التوقيف) regarding what is attributed to this Specifier, whether negation or affirmation, just as one of the speculative theologians (النظار) said to us in a discussion between us, claiming that we must stop there. However, the proof indicates the establishment of the Messenger (الرسول) from the side of the Sender (المرسل). Thus, we took the Divine Relations (النسب الإلهية) from the Messenger and judged that [The Real] is such-and-such and not such-and-such. How can this be, when the clear proof points to His existence (وجوده), and that His existence is the very Essence (عين ذاته) of Him, and is not a cause (علة) for His Essence, since the need for another (الافتقار إلى الغير) is established [for a cause]? He is the Perfect One (الكامل) in every respect. Thus, He is existent, and His existence is His very Essence, and nothing else.

### Issue: Multiplicity of Divine Relations

The dependence (افتقار) of the contingent entity (الممكن) upon the Necessary Being by Essence (الواجب بالذات), and the intrinsic independence (الاستغناء الذاتي) of the Necessary Being over the contingent entity, is called a Deity (إلها).

Its relation (تعلقها) to itself and to the realities (حقائق) of everything realized, whether existence (وجودا) or non-existence (عدما), is called Knowledge (علما).

Its relation to the contingent entities (الممكنات) in terms of what those contingent entities are upon [i.e., their state] is called Choice (اختيارا).

Its relation to the contingent entity in terms of the precedence of Knowledge (العلم) before the contingent entity comes into being is called Will (مشيئة).

Its relation to specifying one of the two possibilities for the contingent entity as definite is called Intention (إرادة).

Its relation to bringing the cosmos (الكون) into existence is called Power (قدرة).

Its relation to making the created thing (المكون) hear, so that it comes into being, is called Command (أمرا). This is of two types: with a means (بواسطة) and without a means (بلا واسطة). When the means are removed, the Command must be executed. But with a means, execution is not necessary, and in the very Reality (عين الحقيقة), it is not a Command, since nothing can stand against the Command of Allah.

Its relation to making the created thing hear, in order to turn it away from its being or from the being of what might issue from it, is called Prohibition (نهيا). Its form in classification is the form of the Command.

Its relation to conveying what [the Essence] or other created things (الكائنات) are upon, or what is in the soul (النفس), is called Information/Reporting (أخبارا).

If it relates to the cosmos by way of "which thing," it is called Interrogation (استفهاما).

If it relates to it by way of descending to it in the form of a command, it is called Supplication (دعاء).

And from the category of the relation of Command to this [whole process], it is called Speech (كلاما).

Its relation to speech without the prerequisite of knowing it is called Hearing (سمعا).

If it relates and the relation is followed by the understanding of what is heard, it is called Comprehension (فهما).

Its relation to the modality of light and what it carries of visible things is called Sight and Vision (بصرا ورؤية).

Its relation to the perception (إدراك) of every perceivable thing, without which none of these relations can be valid, is called Life (حياة).

And the Essence (العين) in all of this is one; the relations (التعلقات) multiplied due to the realities (حقائق) of the related objects and the Names (الأسماء) for the named things (المسميات).

### Issue: Light of Intellect and Faith

The intellect (العقل) has a light (نور) by which it perceives specific matters, and Faith (الإيمان) has a light by which everything is perceived, unless there is an impediment. By the light of the intellect, you reach the knowledge (معرفة) of Divinity (الألوهية), what is necessary for it, what is impossible for it, and what is permissible for it (which is neither impossible nor necessary). And by the light of Faith, the intellect perceives the knowledge of the Essence (الذات) and the descriptions (النعوت) that The Real (الحق) attributed to Himself.

### Issue: Knowledge of the Judgments of the Essence

In our view, it is impossible to know the modality (كيفية) of the judgments (الأحكام) attributed to the essences (الذوات) except after knowing the essences being attributed and the essences to which the attribution is made. Only then will you know the modality of the specific relation (النسبة المخصوصة) for that specific Essence (الذات المخصوصة), such as settling (الاستواء), accompaniment (المعية), the Hand (اليد), the Eye (العين), and so forth.

### Issue: Transmutation of Entities

The entities (الأعيان) do not transmute, and the realities (الحقائق) do not change. Fire burns by its reality, not by its form (صورتها). Thus, His saying, the Exalted: <<يا نارُ كُونِي بَرْداً وسَلاماً>> (O fire, be coolness and peace), was an address to the form, which is the embers. The bodies of the embers are burning by fire. When the fire subsisted in them, they were called fire. Thus, they accepted coolness just as they accepted heat.

### Issue: Subsistence

Subsistence (البقاء) is merely the continuation of existence (الوجود) for the subsisting entity, nothing more. It is not an additional attribute (صفة زائدة) that would require another subsistence, leading to an infinite regress (تسلسل). This is except according to the doctrine of the Ash'aris regarding the originated entity (المحدث), for whom subsistence is an accident (عرض) and thus does not require another subsistence. However, this [non-requirement of another subsistence] applies only to the Subsistence of The Real (الحق تعالى).

### Issue: Speech

Speech (الكلام), in terms of what it is, is one. The division lies in the speaker, not in the Speech itself. Thus, Command (الأمر), Prohibition (النهي), Information (الخبر), Interrogation (الاستخبار), and Request (الطلب) are one in the Speech.

### Issue: The Name, the Named, and the Naming

The difference regarding the Name (الاسم), the Named (المسمى), and the Naming (التسمية) is a difference in wording (اللفظ). As for the saying of those who cite <<تَبارَكَ اسْمُ رَبِّكَ>> (Blessed is the Name of your Lord) and <<سَبِّحِ اسْمَ رَبِّكَ>> (Glorify the Name of your Lord), it is like the prohibition against traveling with the Qur'an to the land of the enemy. As for the argument based on <<أَسْماءٌ سَمَّيْتُمُوها>> (names you have named them) to claim that the Name is the Named, [this is flawed because] the objects of worship are specific entities (الأشخاص), and they worshipped the relation of Divinity (الألوهية). Thus, there is no proof that the Name is the Named. Even if it were so, it would be by the rule of language and convention (الوضع), not by the rule of meaning.

### Issue: Existence of Contingent Entities

The existence (وجود) of contingent entities (الممكنات) is solely for the perfection (كمال) of the levels (مراتب) of Essential (الذاتي) and Gnostic (العرفاني) Existence.

### Issue: Two Divisions of Contingent Existence

Every contingent entity (ممكن) is confined to one of two divisions: in secret (سر) or in theophany (تجل). The contingent entity has thus been found at its furthest and most perfect limit, and there is nothing more perfect than it. If the Most Perfect were inexhaustible, the creation of perfection would not be conceivable. Since [the contingent entity] has been found corresponding to the Presence of Perfection (الحضرة الكمالية), it is complete.

### Issue: Confinement of Known Things

Known things (المعلومات) are confined, in terms of how they are perceived, to external and internal sense (حس ظاهر وباطن)—which is psychic perception (الإدراك النفسي)—and intuition (بديهة), and what is composed from these: intellect (عقلا) if it is meaning, and imagination (خيالا) if it is form. Imagination (الخيال) only composes forms specifically. The intellect (العقل) comprehends what the imagination composes, but it is not within the power of the imagination to form some of what the intellect composes. And for the Divine Power (الاقتدار الإلهي) there is a secret (سر) outside of all this, where [the intellect] stops.

### Issue: Goodness and Ugliness

Goodness (الحسن) and ugliness (القبح) are intrinsic (ذاتي) to the good and the ugly, but some of it is perceived by looking at perfection (كمال) or deficiency (نقص), or purpose (غرض), or suitability to nature (ملاءمة طبع) or aversion to it, or convention (وضع). And some of it, its ugliness or goodness is not perceived except from the side of The Real (الحق), which is the Law (الشرع). So we say, "This is ugly and this is good," and this is information (خبر) from the Law, not a judgment (حكم). For this reason, we stipulate the condition of time, state, and person. We only stipulated this because of those who speak of killing—whether initiated, retaliatory (قودا), or as a legal penalty (حدا)—and of the insertion of the male organ into the female organ, whether illicitly (سفاحا) or through marriage (نكاحا). From the perspective that it is a single act of insertion, we do not speak in this way, for the time is different, and the necessary consequences of marriage are not present in illicit intercourse. The time when a thing is permissible is not the time when it is forbidden, even if the essence (عين) of the forbidden thing were one. Thus, the movement from Zayd at one time is not the movement from him at another time, nor is the movement from Amr the same movement as that from Zayd. Therefore, the ugly thing can never become good, because that movement described as good or ugly never returns. The Real (الحق) has known what was good and what was ugly, while we do not know. Furthermore, it is not necessary that if a thing is ugly, its effect (أثره) must be ugly; its effect may be good. And the good is likewise; its effect may be ugly, such as the goodness of truthfulness (الصدق), which in some places has an ugly effect, and the ugliness of lying (الكذب), which in some places has a good effect. Verify what we have alerted you to, and you will find The Real.

### Issue: The Proof and the Proven

The non-existence of the proof (الدليل) does not necessitate the non-existence of the proven thing (المدلول). Based on this, the saying of the Incarnationist (الحلولي) is invalid: "If Allah were in a thing, as He was in Jesus, He would raise the dead."

### Issue: Contentment with the Decree, not the Decreed

Contentment (الرضا) with the Divine Decree (القضاء) does not necessitate contentment with the Decreed Thing (المقضي). The Decree is the judgment (حكم) of Allah, and He commanded us to be content with it. The Decreed Thing is that which is judged, and we are not obligated to be content with it.

### Issue: Invention

If by invention (الاختراع) is meant the occurrence of the invented meaning in the soul (نفس) of the inventor—which is the true meaning of invention—then that is impossible for Allah. But if by invention is meant the occurrence of the invented thing without a preceding example in the existence (الوجود) in which it appeared, then The Real (الحق) may be described by invention in this sense.

### Issue: The World's Connection to Allah

The connection (ارتباط) of the World (العالم) to Allah is the connection of a contingent entity (ممكن) to a Necessary Being (واجب) and of a created thing (مصنوع) to a Creator (صانع). The World has no level (مرتبة) in pre-eternity (الأزل), for that is the level of the Necessary Being by Essence (الواجب بالذات). He is Allah, and there is nothing with Him, whether the World is existent or non-existent. Therefore, whoever imagines a gap (بونا) between Allah and the World, estimating the precedence or delay of the contingent entity's existence within it, that is a false imagination (توهم باطل) with no reality. For this reason, our method of demonstrating the origination (حدوث) of the World differs from the method adopted by the Ash'aris, as we have mentioned in this commentary.

### Issue: The Relation of Knowledge to the Known

The relation of Knowledge (العلم) to the known thing (المعلوم) does not necessitate the presence of the known thing itself, nor its likeness, in the soul (نفس) of the knower. Rather, Knowledge relates to known things according to the state in which those known things exist, whether in existence (وجودا) or non-existence (عدما). Thus, the saying of one who claims that some known things have four levels (مراتب) of existence: mental (ذهني), external (عيني), verbal (لفظي), and written (خطي)—if he means Knowledge by the mental, it is unacceptable. But if he means Imagination (الخيال) by the mental, it is acceptable, but only in every known thing that is imagined, and in every knower who imagines. However, this is only valid specifically for the mental [level] because it corresponds to the external entity (العين) in form. The verbal and written levels are not like this, for speech and writing are established for indication (الدلالة) and comprehension (التفهيم). They do not descend in terms of form upon the form. For Zayd, in the verbal and written sense, is merely the letters Zāy, Yā’, and Dāl, whether as script or sound, having no right or left, no directions, no eye, and no hearing. For this reason, we said that it does not descend upon him in terms of form, but only in terms of indication. Therefore, when ambiguity (المشاركة) occurs in it, which invalidates the indication, we require description (النعت), substitution (البدل), and apposition (عطف البيان). But ambiguity does not enter the mental level at all. Understand this.

### Issue: Aspects of Knowledge for the First Intellect

In the book *The First Knowledge* we confined the aspects of knowledge (وجوه المعارف) that the Intellect (العقل) possesses in the World (العالم), but we did not point out how we arrived at that confinement. Know that the Intellect has three hundred and sixty aspects (وجها). Each aspect is met by three hundred and sixty aspects from the side of The Mighty Real (الحق العزيز). Each of these aspects supplies it with a knowledge (علم) that the other aspect does not give. If you multiply the aspects of the Intellect by the aspects of reception, the result is the sciences (العلوم) belonging to the Intellect, inscribed in the Preserved Tablet (اللوح المحفوظ), which is the Soul (النفس). What we have mentioned is a Divine Unveiling (كشفا إلهيا) that no rational proof can invalidate. Thus, it is received with acceptance from its speaker—I mean this—just as the three considerations (الاعتبارات) for the First Intellect (العقل الأول) were received from the wise speaker without proof, but merely as an assumption. This is more appropriate than that, for the wise man claims speculation (النظر) in that matter, and he is subject to the objections we mentioned in *The Sources of Issues* regarding the issue of the White Pearl (الدرة البيضاء), which is the First Intellect. What we have mentioned is not subject to objection, for we did not claim it through speculation, but rather through direct knowledge (تعريفا). The utmost the denier can say to the speaker is, "You lie," and nothing else, just as the believer says to him, "You have spoken the truth." This is the distinction (فرقان) between us and those who speak of the three considerations. And with Allah is success.

### Issue: Two Aspects of the Contingent Entity from the World of Creation

There is no contingent entity (ممكن) from the World of Creation (عالم الخلق) except that it has two aspects: an aspect toward its cause (سببه) and an aspect toward Allah, the Exalted. Thus, every veil (حجاب) and darkness (ظلمة) that befalls it is from its cause, and every light (نور) and unveiling (كشف) is from the side of its Reality (حقه). And every contingent entity from the World of Command (عالم الأمر)—no veil is conceivable regarding it, because it has only one aspect. It is Pure Light (النور المحض). <<أَلا لِلَّهِ الدِّينُ الْخالِصُ>> (Indeed, sincere devotion is due to Allah alone).

### Issue: The Object of Command and the Object of Power

Rational proof (الدليل العقلي) indicates that bringing into existence (الإيجاد) is the object of Power (القدرة). And The Real (الحق) said of Himself that existence (الوجود) occurs through the Divine Command (الأمر الإلهي), saying: <<إِنَّما قَوْلُنا لِشَيْ‏ءٍ إِذا أَرَدْناهُ أَنْ نَقُولَ لَهُ كُنْ فَيَكُونُ>> (Indeed, Our word to a thing, when We intend it, is only that We say to it, "Be," and it is). We must therefore examine what the object of the Command is, and what the object of Power is, so that we may reconcile transmitted revelation (السمع) and reason (العقل). We say that compliance (الامتثال) occurred through His saying, "and it is" (فيكون), and the thing commanded is none other than Existence (الوجود). Thus, Intention (الإرادة) related to specifying one of the two possibilities—which is existence—and Power (القدرة) related to the contingent entity (الممكن) and effected the bringing into existence (الإيجاد) within it, which is an intelligible state between non-existence (العدم) and existence (الوجود). The address of the Command related to this specified entity (العين المخصصة) that it should "Be," so it complied and came into being. If the contingent entity had no entity (عين) and no description of existence for it, the Command for existence would not be directed toward that entity, and existence would not occur. And the one who speaks of the preparation of the intended thing in the explanation of "Be" is incorrect.

### Issue: Priority of the Necessary Existent by Another

The intelligibility of priority (الأولية) for the Necessary Existent by Another (الواجب الوجود بالغير) is a negative relation (نسبة سلبية) concerning the existence of Absolute Necessity (الوجوب المطلق). Thus, it is prior (أول) to every restricted thing (مقيد), since it is impossible for it to have pre-eternity (قدم) there. This is because it must either be in the place of Absolute Necessity, in which case it would be either Absolute Necessity itself—which is impossible—or subsisting in it—which is impossible for several reasons, including that it subsists in itself, and including the dependence (الافتقار) that would necessarily apply to the Absolute Necessary if this [contingent necessity] subsisted in it. Thus, it would either be constitutive of its Essence (مقوما لذاته)—which is impossible—or constitutive of its level (مرتبته)—which is also impossible.

### Issue: Priority of the Absolute Necessary

The intelligibility of priority (الأولية) for the Absolute Necessary (الواجب المطلق) is a positive relation (نسبة وضعية) for which the intellect comprehends nothing other than the reliance (استناد) of the contingent entity (الممكن) upon Him. Thus, He is First (أولا) by this consideration. If it were assumed that no contingent entity existed, either potentially or actually, the relation of priority would be negated, as it would find no object to relate to.

### Issue: Our Knowledge of Allah

The most knowledgeable of contingent entities (الممكنات) does not know its Originator (موجده) except in terms of what He is [in relation to the contingent entity]. Thus, the contingent entity itself is knowledge (علم), and anything other than that which is originated from Him is invalid, because knowledge of a thing implies encompassing it and exhausting it, and this is impossible regarding that Divine Presence (الجناب). Therefore, knowledge *of* Him is impossible, and it is not valid to know *from* Him, because He does not admit division. Thus, knowledge remains only of what comes *from* Him, and what comes from Him is you. So, you are the known thing (المعلوم). If it is said, "Our knowledge that He is not such-and-such is knowledge of Him," we reply: Your descriptions (نعوتك) have stripped Him of [those qualities] due to the necessity of negating partnership (نفي المشاركة) indicated by the proof. Thus, you are distinguished in your view from an Essence (ذات) that is unknown to you, in terms of what it is known to itself. It is distinguished for you due to the absence of the affirmative Attributes (الصفات الثبوتية) that it possesses in itself. Understand what you have known and say, "My Lord, increase me in knowledge." If you knew Him, He would not be Him; and if He were ignorant of you, you would not be you. By His knowledge, He brought you into existence, and by your incapacity, you worship Him. He is He for Himself, not for you. And you are you for yourself and for Him. Thus, you are connected to Him, but He is not connected to you. The circle, when absolute, is connected to the point. The point, when absolute, is not connected to the circle. The point of the circle is connected to the circle. Likewise, the Essence (الذات) is absolute and is not connected to you. The Divinity (ألوهية) of the Essence is connected to the worshipped entity (المألوه), like the point of the circle.

### Issue: The Object of Our Vision and Knowledge of Him

The object of our vision (رؤيتنا) of The Real (الحق) is His Essence (ذاته), glory be to Him. And the object of our knowledge (علمنا) of Him is the affirmation of Him as a Deity (إلها) through relations (الإضافات) and negations (السلوب). Thus, the object differs. Therefore, it cannot be said regarding Vision that it is merely an increase in the clarity of Knowledge, due to the difference in the object, even though His existence is the very essence (ماهيته) of Him. We do not deny that the intelligibility of the Essence (الذات) is different from the intelligibility of its being existent.

### Issue: Non-existence is Pure Evil

Some people have not grasped the reality of the statement, "Non-existence (العدم) is Pure Evil (الشر المحض)," due to its subtlety. This is the saying of the verifying scholars (المحققين) among the early and later generations, but they used this phrase without clarifying its meaning. One of the envoys of The Real (سفراء الحق) said to us, in a discussion concerning darkness and light, that goodness (الخير) is in Existence (الوجود) and evil (الشر) is in Non-existence (العدم). Through a long discussion, we came to know that The Real, the Exalted, possesses the absolute release of Existence (إطلاق الوجود) without restriction, and this is Pure Goodness (الخير المحض) in which there is no evil. This is opposed by the absolute release of Non-existence (إطلاق العدم), which is Pure Evil (الشر المحض) in which there is no goodness. This is the meaning of their saying that Non-existence is Pure Evil.

### Issue: Attributing Permissibility to Allah

It is not said, from the perspective of Reality (الحقيقة), that it is permissible (جائز) for Allah to bring a certain matter into existence and permissible for Him not to bring it into existence. For His action upon things is neither contingent (ممكن) when viewed in relation to Him, nor is it necessitated by a necessitating cause (إيجاب موجب). Rather, it is said that *that matter* is permissible to exist and permissible not to exist, and thus it requires a preponderant factor (مرجح), which is Allah, the Exalted. We have examined the Sacred Law (الشريعة) and found nothing in it that contradicts what we have said. What we affirm regarding The Real is that such-and-such is necessary (يجب) for Him and such-and-such is impossible (يستحيل) for Him, but we do not say that such-and-such is permissible (يجوز) for Him. This is the creed (عقيدة) of the people of specialization (أهل الاختصاص) among the People of Allah (أهل الله). As for the creed of the elite of the elite (خلاصة الخاصة) concerning Allah, the Exalted, it is a matter beyond this, which we have scattered throughout this book, because most intellects veiled by their thoughts fall short of grasping it due to their lack of purification (تجريدها). The Introduction (مقدمة) of the book has now concluded, and it is like an appendix to it. Whoever wishes may write it in, and whoever wishes may leave it out. And Allah <<يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (says the truth, and He guides to the way). The Third Volume is concluded, and praise be to Allah.
